entries: When a new sorcerer enters the world, either at birth or later when one's power becomes evident, the consequences of that event depend greatly on how its witnesses react to what they have seen.
When your sorcerer's powers appeared, how did the world around you respond? Were other people supportive, fearful, or somewhere in between?

entries.caption: Reactions
rows: Your powers are seen as a great blessing by those around you, and you are expected to use them in service to your community.
Your powers caused destruction and even a death when they became evident, and you were treated as a criminal.
Your neighbors hate and fear your power, causing them to shun you.
You came to the attention of a sinister cult that plans on exploiting your abilities.
People around you believe that your powers are a curse levied on your family for a past transgression.
Your powers are believed to be tied to an ancient line of mad kings that supposedly ended in a bloody revolt over a century ago.

entries.name: Supernatural Mark
entries: A sorcerer at rest is almost indistinguishable from a normal person; it's only when their magic flies forth that sorcerers reveal their true nature. Even so, many sorcerers have a subtle but telling physical trait that sets them apart from other folk.
If your sorcerer has a supernatural mark, it might be one that's easily concealed, or it could be a source of pride that you keep on constant display.

entries.caption: Supernatural Marks
rows: Your eyes are an unusual color, such as red.
You have an extra toe on one foot.
One of your ears is noticeably larger than the other.
Your hair grows at a prodigious rate.
You wrinkle your nose repeatedly while you are chewing.
A red splotch appears on your neck once a day, then vanishes after an hour.

entries.name: Signs of Sorcery
entries: As the world well knows, some sorcerers are better than others at controlling their spellcasting. Sometimes a wild display of magic gone awry emanates from a sorcerer who casts a spell. But even when one's magic goes off as planned, the act of casting is often accompanied by a telltale sign that makes it clear where that magical energy came from.

When your sorcerer character casts a spell, does the effort reveal itself in a sign of sorcery? Is this sign tied to your origin or some other aspect of who you are, or is it a seemingly random phenomenon?

entries.caption: Signs of Sorcery
rows: You deliver the verbal components of your spells in the booming voice of a titan.
For a moment after you cast a spell, the area around you grows dark and gloomy.
You sweat profusely while casting a spell and for a few seconds thereafter.
Your hair and garments are briefly buffeted about, as if by a breeze, whenever you call forth a spell.
If you are standing when you cast a spell, you rise six inches into the air and gently float back down.
Illusory blue flames wreathe your head as you begin your casting, then abruptly disappear.

default: (a) a {@item quarterstaff|phb} or (b) a {@item dagger|phb}
(a) a {@item component pouch|phb} or (b) an {@item arcane focus|phb}
(a) a {@item scholar's pack|phb} or (b) an {@item explorer's pack|phb}
A {@item spellbook|phb}

fluff.name: Wizard
entries: Clad in the silver robes that denote her station, an elf closes her eyes to shut out the distractions of the battlefield and begins her quiet chant. Fingers weaving in front of her, she completes her spell and launches a tiny bead of fire toward the enemy ranks, where it erupts into a conflagration that engulfs the soldiers.

Checking and rechecking his work, a human scribes an intricate magic circle in chalk on the bare stone floor, then sprinkles powdered iron along every line and graceful curve. When the circle is complete, he drones a long incantation. A hole opens in space inside the circle, bringing a whiff of brimstone from the otherworldly plane beyond.

Crouching on the floor in a dungeon intersection, a gnome tosses a handful of small bones inscribed with mystic symbols, muttering a few words of power over them. Closing his eyes to see the visions more clearly, he nods slowly, then opens his eyes and points down the passage to his left.

Wizards are supreme magic-users, defined and united as a class by the spells they cast. Drawing on the subtle weave of magic that permeates the cosmos, wizards cast spells of explosive fire, arcing lightning, subtle deception, and brute-force mind control. Their magic conjures monsters from other planes of existence, glimpses the future, or turns slain foes into zombies. Their mightiest spells change one substance into another, call meteors down from the sky, or open portals to other worlds.

entries.name: Scholars of the Arcane
entries: Wild and enigmatic, varied in form and function, the power of magic draws students who seek to master its mysteries. Some aspire to become like the gods, shaping reality itself. Though the casting of a typical spell requires merely the utterance of a few strange words, fleeting gestures, and sometimes a pinch or clump of exotic materials, these surface components barely hint at the expertise attained after years of apprenticeship and countless hours of study.

Wizards live and die by their spells. Everything else is secondary. They learn new spells as they experiment and grow in experience. They can also learn them from other wizards, from ancient tomes or inscriptions, and from ancient creatures (such as the fey) that are steeped in magic.

entries.name: The Lure of Knowledge
entries: Wizards' lives are seldom mundane. The closest a wizard is likely to come to an ordinary life is working as a sage or lecturer in a library or university, teaching others the secrets of the multiverse. Other wizards sell their services as diviners, serve in military forces, or pursue lives of crime or domination.

But the lure of knowledge and power calls even the most unadventurous wizards out of the safety of their libraries and laboratories and into crumbling ruins and lost cities. Most wizards believe that their counterparts in ancient civilizations knew secrets of magic that have been lost to the ages, and discovering those secrets could unlock the path to a power greater than any magic available in the present age.

entries.name: Creating a Wizard
entries: Creating a wizard character demands a backstory dominated by at least one extraordinary event. How did your character first come into contact with magic? How did you discover you had an aptitude for it? Do you have a natural talent, or did you simply study hard and practice incessantly? Did you encounter a magical creature or an ancient tome that taught you the basics of magic?

What drew you forth from your life of study? Did your first taste of magical knowledge leave you hungry for more? Have you received word of a secret repository of knowledge not yet plundered by any other wizard? Perhaps you're simply eager to put your newfound magical skills to the test in the face of danger.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a wizard quickly by following these suggestions. First, Intelligence should be your highest ability score, followed by Constitution or Dexterity. If you plan to join the School of Enchantment, make Charisma your next-best score. Second, choose the {@background sage} background. Third, choose the {@spell mage hand}, {@spell light}, and {@spell ray of frost} cantrips, along with the following 1st-level spells for your spellbook: {@spell burning hands}, {@spell charm person}, {@spell feather fall}, {@spell mage armor}, {@spell magic missile}, and {@spell sleep}.
Wizardry requires understanding. The knowledge of how and why magic works, and our efforts to broaden that understanding, have brought about the key advances in civilization over the centuries.

Only a select few people in the world are wielders of magic. Of all those, wizards stand at the pinnacle of the craft. Even the least of them can manipulate forces that flout the laws of nature, and the most accomplished among them can cast spells with world-shaking effects.

The price that wizards pay for their mastery is that most valuable of commodities: time. It takes years of study, instruction, and experimentation to learn how to harness magical energy and carry spells around in one's own mind. For adventuring wizards and other spellcasters who aspire to the highest echelons of the profession, the studying never ends, nor does the quest for knowledge and power.

If you're playing a wizard, take advantage of the opportunity to make your character more than just a stereotypical spell-slinger. Use the advice that follows to add some intriguing details to how your wizard interacts with the world.

entries.name: Spellbook
entries: Your wizard character's most prized possession—your spellbook—might be an innocuous-looking volume whose covers show no hint of what's inside. Or you might display some flair, as many wizards do, by carrying a spellbook of an unusual sort. If you don't own such an item already, one of your goals might be to find a spellbook that sets you apart by its appearance or its means of manufacture.

entries.caption: Spellbooks
rows: A tome with pages that are thin sheets of metal, spells etched into them with acid
Long straps of leather on which spells are written, wrapped around a staff for ease of transport
A battered tome filled with pictographs that only you can understand
Small stones inscribed with spells and kept in a cloth bag
A scorched book, ravaged by dragon fire, with the script of your spells barely visible on its pages
A tome full of black pages whose writing is visible only in dim light or darkness

entries.name: Ambition
entries: Few aspiring wizards undertake the study of magic without some personal goal in mind. Many wizards use their spells as a tool to produce a tangible benefit, in material goods or in status, for themselves or their companions. For others, the theoretical aspect of magic might have a strong appeal, pushing those wizards to seek out knowledge that supports new theories of the arcane or confirms old ones.

Beyond the obvious, why does your wizard character study magic, and what do you want to achieve? If you haven't given these questions much thought, you can do so now, and the answers you come up with will likely affect how your future unfolds.

entries.caption: Ambitions
rows: You will prove that the gods aren't as powerful as folk believe.
Immortality is the end goal of your studies.
If you can fully understand magic, you can unlock its use for all and usher in an era of equality.
Magic is a dangerous tool. You use it to protect what you treasure.
Arcane power must be taken away from those who would abuse it.
You will become the greatest wizard the world has seen in generations.

entries.name: Eccentricity
entries: Endless hours of solitary study and research can have a negative effect on anyone's social skills. Wizards, who are a breed apart to begin with, are no exception. An odd mannerism or two is not necessarily a drawback, though; an eccentricity of this sort is usually harmless and could provide a source of amusement or serve as a calling card of sorts.

If your character has an eccentricity, is it a physical tic or a mental one? Are you well known in some circles because of it? Do you fight to overcome it, or do you embrace this minor claim to fame of yours?

entries.caption: Eccentricities
rows: You have the habit of tapping your foot incessantly, which often annoys those around you.
Your memory is quite good, but you have no trouble pretending to be absentminded when it suits your purposes.
You never enter a room without looking to see what's hanging from the ceiling.
Your most prized possession is a dead worm that you keep inside a potion vial.
When you want people to leave you alone, you start talking to yourself. That usually does the trick.
Your fashion sense and grooming, or more accurately lack thereof, sometimes cause others to assume you are a beggar.

default: (a) a {@item light crossbow|tct} and {@item crossbow bolts (20)|phb|20 bolts} or (b) any {@filter simple weapon|items|source=tct|category=basic|type=simple weapon}
(a) a {@item component pouch|phb} or (b) an {@item arcane focus|phb}
(a) a {@item scholar's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb}
{@item Leather armor|phb}, any {@filter simple weapon|items|source=tct|category=basic|type=simple weapon}, and two {@item dagger|tct|daggers}

fluff.name: Warlock
entries: With a pseudodragon curled on his shoulder, a young elf in golden robes smiles warmly, weaving a magical charm into his honeyed words and bending the palace sentinel to his will.
As flames spring to life in her hands, a wizened human whispers the secret name of her demonic patron, infusing her spell with fiendish magic.
Shifting his gaze between a battered tome and the odd alignment of the stars overhead, a wild-eyed tiefling chants the mystic ritual that will open a doorway to a distant world.

Warlocks are seekers of the knowledge that lies hidden in the fabric of the multiverse. Through pacts made with mysterious beings of supernatural power, warlocks unlock magical effects both subtle and spectacular. Drawing on the ancient knowledge of beings such as fey nobles, demons, devils, hags, and alien entities of the Far Realm, warlocks piece together arcane secrets to bolster their own power.

entries.name: Sworn and Beholden
entries: A warlock is defined by a pact with an otherworldly being. Sometimes the relationship between warlock and patron is like that of a cleric and a deity, though the beings that serve as patrons for warlocks are not gods. A warlock might lead a cult dedicated to a demon prince, an archdevil, or an utterly alien entity—beings not typically served by clerics. More often, though, the arrangement is similar to that between a master and an apprentice. The warlock learns and grows in power, at the cost of occasional services performed on the patron's behalf.

The magic bestowed on a warlock ranges from minor but lasting alterations to the warlock's being (such as the ability to see in darkness or to read any language) to access to powerful spells. Unlike bookish wizards, warlocks supplement their magic with some facility at hand-to-hand combat. They are comfortable in light armor and know how to use simple weapons.

entries.name: Delvers into Secrets
entries: Warlocks are driven by an insatiable need for knowledge and power, which compels them into their pacts and shapes their lives. This thirst drives warlocks into their pacts and shapes their later careers as well.

Stories of warlocks binding themselves to fiends are widely known. But many warlocks serve patrons that are not fiendish. Sometimes a traveler in the wilds comes to a strangely beautiful tower, meets its fey lord or lady, and stumbles into a pact without being fully aware of it. And sometimes, while poring over tomes of forbidden lore, a brilliant but crazed student's mind is opened to realities beyond the material world and to the alien beings that dwell in the outer void.

Once a pact is made, a warlock's thirst for knowledge and power can't be slaked with mere study and research. No one makes a pact with such a mighty patron if he or she doesn't intend to use the power thus gained. Rather, the vast majority of warlocks spend their days in active pursuit of their goals, which typically means some kind of adventuring. Furthermore, the demands of their patrons drive warlocks toward adventure.

entries.name: Creating a Warlock
entries: As you make your warlock character, spend some time thinking about your patron and the obligations that your pact imposes upon you. What led you to make the pact, and how did you make contact with your patron? Were you seduced into summoning a devil, or did you seek out the ritual that would allow you to make contact with an alien elder god? Did you search for your patron, or did your patron find and choose you? Do you chafe under the obligations of your pact or serve joyfully in anticipation of the rewards promised to you?

Work with your DM to determine how big a part your pact will play in your character's adventuring career. Your patron's demands might drive you into adventures, or they might consist entirely of small favors you can do between adventures.

What kind of relationship do you have with your patron? Is it friendly, antagonistic, uneasy, or romantic? How important does your patron consider you to be? What part do you play in your patron's plans? Do you know other servants of your patron?

How does your patron communicate with you? If you have a familiar, it might occasionally speak with your patron's voice. Some warlocks find messages from their patrons etched on trees, mingled among tea leaves, or adrift in the clouds—messages that only the warlock can see. Other warlocks converse with their patrons in dreams or waking visions, or deal only with intermediaries.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a warlock quickly by following these suggestions. First, Charisma should be your highest ability score, followed by Constitution. Second, choose the {@background charlatan} background. Third, choose the {@spell eldritch blast} and {@spell chill touch} cantrips, along with the 1st-level spells {@spell charm person} and {@spell witch bolt}.
You think me mad? I think true insanity is being content to live a life of mortal drudgery when knowledge and power is there for the taking in the realm beyond.

Warlocks are finders and keepers of secrets. They push at the edge of our understanding of the world, always seeking to expand their expertise. Where sages or wizards might heed a clear sign of danger and end their research, a warlock plunges ahead, heedless of the cost. Thus, it takes a peculiar mixture of intelligence, curiosity, and recklessness to produce a warlock. Many folk would describe that combination as evidence of madness. Warlocks see it as a demonstration of bravery.

Warlocks are defined by two elements that work in concert to forge their path into this class. The first element is the event or circumstances that led to a warlock's entering into a pact with a planar entity. The second one is the nature of the entity a warlock is bound to. Unlike clerics, who typically embrace a deity and that god's ethos, a warlock might have no love for a patron, or vice versa.
The sections that follow provide ways to embellish a warlock character that could generate some intriguing story and roleplaying opportunities.

entries.name: Patron's Attitude
entries: Every relationship is a two-way street, but in the case of warlocks and their patrons it's not necessarily true that both sides of the street are the same width or made of the same stuff. The feeling that a warlock holds for their patron, whether positive or negative, might be reciprocated by the patron, or the two participants in the pact might view one another with opposing emotions.

When you determine the attitude your warlock character holds toward your patron, also consider how things look from the patron's perspective. How does your patron behave toward you? Is your patron a friend and ally, or an enemy that grants you power only because you forced a pact upon it?

entries.caption: Patron Attitudes
rows: Your patron has guided and helped your family for generations and is kindly toward you.
Each interaction with your capricious patron is a surprise, whether pleasant or painful.
Your patron is the spirit of a long-dead hero who sees your pact as a way for it to continue to influence the world.
Your patron is a strict disciplinarian but treats you with a measure of respect.
Your patron tricked you into a pact and treats you as a slave.
You are mostly left to your own devices with no interference from your patron. Sometimes you dread the demands it will make when it does appear.

entries.name: Special Terms of the Pact
entries: A pact can range from a loose agreement to a formal contract with lengthy, detailed clauses and lists of requirements. The terms of a pact—what a warlock must do to receive a patron's favor—are always dictated by the patron. On occasion, those terms include a special proviso that might seem odd or whimsical, but warlocks take these dictates as seriously as they do the other requirements of their pacts.

Does your character have a pact that requires you to change your behavior in an unusual or seemingly frivolous way? Even if your patron hasn't imposed such a duty on you already, that's not to say it couldn't still happen.

entries.caption: Special Terms
rows: When directed, you must take immediate action against a specific enemy of your patron.
Your pact tests your willpower; you are required to abstain from alcohol and other intoxicants.
At least once a day, you must inscribe or carve your patron's name or symbol on the wall of a building.
You must occasionally conduct bizarre rituals to maintain your pact.
You can never wear the same outfit twice, since your patron finds such predictability to be boring.
When you use an eldritch invocation, you must speak your patron's name aloud or risk incurring its displeasure.

entries.name: Binding Mark
entries: Some patrons make a habit of, and often enjoy, marking the warlocks under their sway in some fashion. A binding mark makes it clear—to those who know about such things—that the individual in question is bound to the patron's service. A warlock might take advantage of such a mark, claiming it as proof of one's pact, or might want to keep it under wraps (if possible) to avoid the difficulties it might bring.

If your warlock's pact comes with a binding mark, how you feel about displaying it probably depends on the nature of your relationship with the one who gave it to you. Is the mark a source of pride or something you are secretly ashamed of?

entries.caption: Binding Marks
rows: One of your eyes looks the same as one of your patron's eyes.
Each time you wake up, the small blemish on your face appears in a different place.
You display outward symptoms of a disease but suffer no ill effects from it.
Your tongue is an unnatural color.
Your nose glows in the dark.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: As a master of illusion and mental manipulation, you can cast mesmer spells. Your magic weaves complex illusions and manipulates the minds of those around you, bending perceptions to your will and controlling the flow of battle through cunning and subtlety.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know three cantrips of your choice from the {@filter mesmer spell list|spells|class=mesmer (AGI)}. You gain additional mesmer cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Mesmer table.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Mesmer table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your mesmer spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of mesmer spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the {@filter mesmer spell list|spells|class=mesmer (AGI)}. When you do so, choose a number of mesmer spells equal to your Intelligence modifier + your mesmer level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you are a 3rd-level mesmer, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With an Intelligence of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell {@spell illusionary force}, you can cast it using a 1st-level or 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of mesmer spells requires time spent in meditation and mental exercises: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your mesmer spells, as your magic hinges on your ability to deceive, manipulate, and outsmart. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a mesmer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast any mesmer spell you know as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your mesmer spells. Mesmers often use objects that reflect their personal flair and the theatrical nature of their magic, such as mirrors, masks, or crystal orbs, as their arcane focuses. To use such an item, you must spend an hour in concentration, imbuing it with your magical essence.

classFeature.name: Replicate
entries: Harnessing your mastery over illusion, you have the unique ability to create and manipulate clones of yourself to confuse, distract, and damage your enemies. These replicas are fundamental to your tactics, providing both offensive and defensive capabilities.

entries.name: Clone Creation
entries: At 1st level, you gain the Replicate ability, allowing you to create clones. A clone mimics your actions and serves as a distraction, it has the same AC as you had at the moment it was created, having 1 hit point and causing attacks against it to be made with disadvantage. It uses your modifiers to make saving throws.
At any point, you can have as many clones active as your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Mirror Image
entries: Whenever you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can create a clone of yourself in an unoccupied space within 30 feet. The clone lasts for 1 minute or until destroyed.

entries.name: Decoy
entries: As a bonus action on your turn, create a clone in your space that lasts for 1 minute or until destroyed. You can then move up to your speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

entries.name: I'm The Real One!!!
entries: At the end of your turn, you can command one of your clones to make a single attack against a target within its range. Make a melee spell attack against a target within 5ft of a clone. On a hit, it deals psychic damage equal to {@dice 1d4} + your Intelligence modifier.

classFeature.name: Shatter
entries: At 2nd level, your mastery over illusions deepens, granting you the power to shatter your clones for devastating effects. Each shatter ability triggers a unique effect that scales with the number of clones you shatter.

entries.name: Shatter Style
entries: Using a bonus action, you can shatter any number of your active clones within 60 feet. The effects of shattering are enhanced by the number of clones shattered, making your illusions more than mere distractions.

entries.name: Mind Wrack
entries: Shatter your clones to deal psychic damage to all enemies adjacent to each clone. Damage each clone deals increases with the number of clones: {@dice 1d6} for one clone, {@dice 2d6} for two clones, doubling the dice for each additional clone shattered.

entries.name: Cry of Frustration
entries: Shatter your clones to inflict confusion on enemies near the clones. Each creature that is adjacent to a clone must make a wisdom saving throw or be {@i confused} till the end of its next turn. Creatures next to multiple clones need to make multiple saving throws.

A {@i confused} creature on its turn is muddled with defening thoughts as the clones cries ring out. It may use its action to focus and end the confusion. If it uses its action, bonus action, movement or reaction to do anything else while confused, it takes {@dice 1d8} psychic damage and the confusion ends. The damage increases with the number of clones shattered. {@dice 1d8} for 1 clone, {@dice 2d8} for 2 clones and so on.

entries.name: Diversion
entries: Shatter your clones to daze and disrupts your enemies. Each creature that is adjacent to a clone must make a dexterity saving throw or immediately lose thier reactions. Creatures next to multiple clones need to make multiple saving throws. If a creature was concentrating, it also needs to make a contitution saving throw to maintain concentration. The DC for which is enhanced by the number of clones you shatter. DC 10 + Shattered clones.

entries.name: Distortion
entries: Shatter your clones to and grant yourself a moment of invulnerability. You gain a pool of {@dice d6}'s that you can use to reduce damage dealt to you. The pool is as large as the number of clones shattered.
When you take damage, you can roll dice from this pool and reduce the damage by that amount after any reductions from resistance.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Illusory Onslaught
entries: At 6th level, your mastery over illusions allows you to weave them into more complex and damaging forms. Your illusions are now capable of executing a simultaneous attack, overwhelming your foes with a barrage of strikes from multiple angles.

entries.name: Enhanced Clone Attack
entries: Whenever you use your 'I'm The Real One!!!' ability to command one of your clones to attack, you can now make a second attack with another clone against the same target or a different one within range. Each attack uses your spell attack modifier and deals psychic damage equal to 1d4 + your Intelligence modifier. This ability represents your clones' enhanced capacity to harm, further blurring the line between illusion and reality.

entries.name: Tactical Reposition
entries: In addition, whenever you create a clone using any of your abilities, you can choose to swap places with any one of your existing clones on the battlefield. This swap can be triggered once per turn, allowing you to reposition strategically without provoking opportunity attacks, enhancing your battlefield mobility and deceit.

classFeature.name: Master of Mirrors
entries: At 18th level, your command over illusions allows you to manipulate the fabric of reality itself. You become a Master of Mirrors, able to create perfect reflections of reality that can harm, protect, or deceive.

entries.name: Reality's Reflection
entries: As an action, you can create a mirrored area on the battlefield up to 30 feet in diameter within 120 feet of you. This area becomes a reflection of reality for 1 minute. Enemies within the area are subjected to disorienting visions, granting advantage on attacks against them. Allies within the area receive a reflection of themselves that can take a single hit in their stead, disappearing afterward.

entries.name: Mirror Walk
entries: Once per long rest, you can step into one mirror and emerge from another within 1 mile that you have seen before. This teleportation can be used to traverse great distances instantly, escape danger, or enter secured locations.

entries.name: Ultimate Shatter
entries: You gain the ability to perform an Ultimate Shatter, instantly ending all of your active illusions and causing a massive explosion of psychic energy. Each enemy within 30 feet of a shattered illusion takes 10d6 psychic damage, and must make an Intelligence saving throw or be stunned until the end of their next turn. This ability can be used once per long rest.

classFeature.name: Quantum Illusionist
entries: At 20th level, you achieve the pinnacle of illusion mastery, becoming a Quantum Illusionist. Your understanding of reality, illusion, and the space between allows you to manipulate the fabric of existence itself, altering outcomes to your advantage.

entries.name: Quantum Flux
entries: Once per long rest, as an action, you can activate Quantum Flux. For the next minute, you gain the following benefits:
- You can reroll any attack roll, saving throw, or ability check made by you or against you, choosing the preferred outcome.
- When you or any of your allies within 60 feet of you take damage, you can use your reaction to halve that damage.
- You can teleport up to 30 feet as a bonus action on each of your turns.

entries.name: Reality Warp
entries: In addition, you gain the ability to cast the spell 'wish' once, without needing material components. After you use this ability, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

classFeature.name: Mesmer Elite Specialization
entries: At 3rd level, Mesmers choose a specialization that provides unique abilities and enhancements:

items: Chronomancer: Masters of time, Chronomancers can manipulate the flow of battle, offering abilities like speeding up ally actions or creating temporal fields that slow enemies.
Mirage: Specializing in deception, Mirages gain abilities to evade attacks, create more convincing illusions, and even make their clones perform semi-independent actions.
Illusionist: Focusing on the potency of their illusions, Illusionists enhance the durability and effects of their clones, and gain abilities that make their shattering effects more devastating.

entries.name: Choosing Your Path
entries: When you choose your specialization at 3rd level, you gain specific abilities related to that path. These abilities are designed to complement and enhance your existing Mesmer skills, providing new tactical options and strategies.

classFeature.name: Elite Specialization
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Elite Specialization.

classFeature.name: Elite Specialization
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Elite Specialization.

classFeature.name: Elite Specialization
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Elite Specialization.

classFeature.name: Echoes of Infinity
entries: Achieving level 21, you unlock the ability to call upon your alternate selves from different realities for assistance, manifesting the true power of a Quantum Illusionist.

entries.name: Multiversal Assistance
entries: Once per long rest, as an action, you can summon an echo of yourself from an alternate reality. This echo appears within 30 feet of you and possesses all the abilities and spells you have but cannot use 'Echoes of Infinity'. It acts on your initiative and follows your commands mentally. The echo lasts for 1 minute or until it drops to 0 hit points.

classFeature.name: Paradoxical Existence
entries: At 22nd level, your grasp on the fabric of reality allows you to blur the lines between presence and absence, existing in multiple realities simultaneously.

entries.name: Ubiquitous Presence
entries: You can spend 10 minutes to create a duplicate of yourself that lasts for 24 hours. This duplicate can perform any action you can, including spellcasting, but it cannot create another duplicate with 'Paradoxical Existence'. You can have up to two duplicates at any time, and you share a mental link, allowing you to see through their eyes and communicate.
If a duplicate is killed, you must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or suffer one level of exhaustion. Duplicates disappear if they are killed or when the duration ends.

classFeature.name: Analysis
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can quickly analyze a foe's strengths and weaknesses. As a bonus action, you can Mark a creature you can see within 60 feet, gaining the following benefits for 1 minute or until you Mark another creature:

items: You can use Intelligence, in place of Strength or Dexterity, for your attack and damage rolls against that creature.

If you hit the creature with an attack, or observe it for 1 minute, you learn one of the following characteristics of your choice: Armour Class, speed, one ability score, one of its senses, its maximum hit points, or its creature type.
You have advantage on any Intelligence or Wisdom-based ability checks you make to analyze the creature.

entries: You can also use a bonus action to make an ability check using any Intelligence or Wisdom skill proficiency you have.

classFeature.name: Perfect Recall
entries: You can recall picture-perfect details from things you commit to memory. Starting at 1st level, if you spend at least 1 minute observing something, you can recall any information about it, at any point in the future, without requiring an ability check.

classFeature.name: Unarmoured Defense
entries: Your observant style of fighting allows you to anticipate and dodge attacks. Starting at 1st level, when you are not wearing any armour or wielding a shield, your Armour Class is equal to 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Intelligence modifier.

classFeature.name: Mental Dice
entries: At 2nd level, you gain a pool of Mental Dice which represent your mental limits. When you make an ability check or saving throw that uses Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma, you can expend one of these Dice and add it to your roll. You can do so after you roll, but before you know if you succeed or fail. You have a total number of Mental Dice equal to your Wisdom modifier + your Intelligence modifier, regaining all expended Dice when you finish a short or long rest.
Your Mental Dice begin as {@dice d4}s, and increase in size as you gain levels in this class, as indicated in the Prodigy table.

classFeature.name: Fault Finding
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can point out weak points for your allies. When a creature you can see hits the target you've marked with Analysis, you can as a reaction increase the attack's damage by an amount equal to your Mental Die.
When you reach 5th level, Attacks you make can trigger this reaction as well and at 11th level, the damage of the triggering attack increases by two rolls of your Mental Die.

classFeature.name: Intellectual Pursuit
entries: At 3rd level, choose your Intellectual Pursuit: (only Tactician for now sorry), each of which is detailed at the end of this class. Your Pursuit grants you features at 3rd level, and again at 6th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Improved Reflexes
entries: Starting at 5th level, you gain one additional reaction you can take each round. A single trigger can only trigger one reaction.
While not surprised, you may add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1) to your initiative rolls.

classFeature.name: Skilled Student
entries: Your ability to learn astounds. Beginning at 5th level, each time you finish a long rest, you can choose to learn one additional language, or gain proficiency in one tool, skill, or weapon of your choice, as long as there is an example for you to learn from (such as a willing teacher with that proficiency, a manual, or a book in a different language). You can only learn one new proficiency or language from this feature per long rest.

You can use this feature to learn a total number of extra proficiencies and languages equal to your proficiency bonus. If you learn another language or proficiency while you are at your maximum, you must choose one language or proficiency you gained through this feature forget, as your mind can only remember so many hastily learned skills and abilities at once. When you replace a language or proficiency you immediately lose any skill or knowledge of it.
When you reach 10th level in this class, you can learn a language or proficiency at the end of each short or long rest.

classFeature.name: Intellectual Pursuit Feature
entries: At 6th level you gain a feature granted by your Intellectual Pursuit.

classFeature.name: Keen Awareness
entries: You are quick to notice danger. Starting at 7th level, you cannot be surprised unless you are {@condition incapacitated}.
In addition, when you roll initiative, you can use Analysis to Mark a creature you can see within 60 feet.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Skilled Instructor
entries: Starting at 9th level, you become proficient in tutoring. During a long rest, you choose a number of creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier. then choose one tool, skill, or weapon proficiency, or one language you know. The creatures gain that proficiency or learn to understand and speak some rudiments of the language until the end of your next long rest.

classFeature.name: Flawless Observation
entries: Starting at 11th level, you can use Potent Observation when a creature hits another creature you can see with a weapon attack, even if the target is not marked by Analysis.
Also, if you use Potent Observation to increase the damage against the creature marked by your Analysis you add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1) to the damage.

classFeature.name: Potent Observation
entries: Beginning at 11th level, this reaction increases the damage of the triggering attack by two rolls of your Mental Die.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level,  you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Intellectual Pursuit Feature
entries: At 13th level you gain a feature granted by your Intellectual Pursuit.

classFeature.name: Unyielding Will
entries: Starting at 14th level, when you fail a saving throw to resist being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, or {@condition stunned}, you can expend a Mental Die to automatically succeed instead.
Additionally, when you roll initiative with no Mental Dice remaining, you instantly regain one expended Mental Die.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level,  you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Intellectual Pursuit Feature
entries: At 17th level you gain a feature granted by your Intellectual Pursuit.

classFeature.name: Advanced Reflexes
entries: Upon reaching 17th level, your reflexes near their pinnacles, allowing for another reaction per round (totalling to 3).

classFeature.name: Instant Cognition
entries: You can predict the movements and intentions of the creatues you mark. Starting at 18th level, a creature marked by your Analysis has disadvantage on attack rolls they make against you, and you gain advantage on saving throws they force on you.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level,  you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Unparalleled Genius
entries: Upon reaching 20th level, you reach the true potential of your mind. Your Intelligence and Wisdom scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: As a Flickwrist your specialty is the learning and mastery of movement to cast Cantrips. As you progress through this class you will gain abilities that strengthen and quicken the casting of them.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the {@filter wizard spell list|spells|level=0|class=wizard}, they count as Flickwrist cantrips. You learn additional wizard cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Flickwrist table. You may replace a cantrip you know with with another from the wizard spell list when you gain a level in this class.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Flickwrist spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your wizard spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest. For example, if you know the 1st-level spell shield and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast shield using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: At 1st level, You know three 1st-level {@filter wizard spells|spells|level=1|class=wizard} of your choice. The Spells Known column of the Flickwrist Spellcasting table shows when you learn more wizard spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the wizard spells you know with another spell of your choice from the wizard spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellasting Ability
entries: Dexterity is your spellcasting ability for casting spells. Your finesse in its casting determines the spells potency. You use your Dexterity whenever a Spell refers to your Spellcasting ability. You also use your Dexterity modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a Flickwrist Cantrip you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an article of clothing or a worn accessory as a spellcasting focus.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 1st level, choose one of your skill proficiencies, a tool or musical instrument you're proficient with. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 6th level, you can choose one more of your proficiencies (in skills, tools or musical instruments) to gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Choreurgic Art
entries: At the 2nd Level, You choose a school of spelldance to guide your movements. Your choice grants you different features at 6th, 10th and 14th Levels.

classFeature.name: Casting Style
entries: At 2nd level, you adopt a particular style of spellcasting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take a Casting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

entries.name: Elusion
entries: While you aren't wearing medium armour, heavy armour or shields, you gain a +1 to AC.

entries.name: Fluency
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged spell attacks.

entries.name: Potency
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to your spell save DCs for cantrips you cast.

entries.name: Deflection
entries: You can use your reaction to grant a creature within 5 feet of you advantage against a spells saving throw. You must have both your hands free.

entries.name: Spellbending
entries: Cantrips you cast ignore half and three-quarters cover. If there is and an unobstructed path of a length less than or equal to the range exists between you and the target behind total cover, it can be targeted by cantrips that require sight but the target has advantage on any of its saves and attack rolls against it will be at disadvantage.

entries.name: Close-Quarters Casting
entries: Being within 5 feet of an enemy does not impose disadvantage on ranged cantrips that you cast.

entries.name: Esotericism
entries: Choose 2 cantrips from the {@filter Druid|spells|level=0|class=Druid}, {@filter Cleric|spells|level=0|class=Cleric} or {@filter Bard|spells|level=0|class=Bard} spell lists and add it to the cantrips you know. They now count as Flickwrist cantrips but do not count towards your cantrips known limit.

entries.name: Stability
entries: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for a spell you cast, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2.

classFeature.name: Choreurgic Masteries
entries: As you deepen your study of the Choreurgic arts, you begin to discover new intricacies to your step that change how you dance or the way you cast spells.

At the 3rd Level, you gain two Choreurgic Masteries of your choice from the list {@filter here|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=FW:CM}. They are powerful abilities that you gain throughout the course of this class as shown in the 'Masteries Known' table.
Additionally when you gain a mastery, you may replace one that you know for another that you meet the requirements for.

You may learn a mastery at the same time that you meet its requirements. If a mastery has a level requirement, you must be a Flickwrist of that level. If you change something about yourself such that you don't meet choreurgic mastery's prerequisites, the mastery and its effects are disabled until its prerequisites are met again or the mastery changed entirely.

classFeature.name: Potent Cantrip
entries: At the 3rd Level, your damaging cantrips affect even creatures that avoid the brunt of the effect. When a creature succeeds on a saving throw against your cantrip, the creature takes half the cantrip's damage (if any) but suffers no additional effect from the cantrip.
In additon, when a cantrip that requires a spell attack hits, you can add your Dexterity modifier to one damage roll of the attack.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Tachyurgy
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can cast two cantrips, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action cast a spell} action on your turn.
Unless you have the Extra Attack feature, only one of those cantrips cast can involve a weapon attack.

classFeature.name: Augments

entries.name: Choreurgic Capacity & Repletion
entries: The amount of vigour slots a Flickwrist can store is his Choreurgic Capacity. When your character reaches the 5th, 11th and 17th level it goes up by one. Though Flickwrists can gain additional vigour slots at certain levels shown in the Flickwrist table.

During the course of a battle, spent vigour slots will recover at a certain rate. This rate is represented by your Choreurgic repletion. Your Character's level determines how many vigour slots he recovers.
It is 1 at 1st Level, then increases by 1 on the 5th, 11th and 17th level.
When you enter spelldance, you will recover an amount determined by your Choreurgic Repletion.
If you have entered spelldance by the time your turn ends, you will recover vigour slots according to your Choreurgic repletion.

At the 5th Level, You've learnt to channel the vigour within to perform various feats. When entering spelldance you can choose to spend some vigour slots to apply one augment to your spelldance. You learn to use two at this level and learn one more at 9th and 15th level.
When reaching a level in this class that grants a Feat or an ASI. you can choose to swap one of the Augments for another.

entries.name: Mummer's Dance
entries: The Flickwrist spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your wizard spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest. For example, if you know the 1st-level spell shield and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast shield using either slot.

entries.name: Zephyr's Dance
entries: When you enter spelldance you can use a bonus action and any number of vigour slots to gain movement equal to 5 feet per slot. This movement provokes no opportunity attacks.

entries.name: Dance of Agony
entries: You can spend 3 vigour slots on to enhance Cantrips cast within this spelldance. Any saving throw incurred by the Cantrip is made at disadvantage.

entries.name: Mollifying Dance
entries: You can spend a vigour slot to impose a {@dice 1d4} penalty to creatures when making a saving throw for a Cantrip cast in the spell dance.

entries.name: Dance of Crashing Waves
entries: You can spend a number of vigour slots on this dance. if a large or smaller creature fails a saving throw for one Cantrip cast in the spell dance it is pushed number of feet away or closer equal to 5 times the vigour slots used

entries.name: Biding Dance
entries: You can spend a vigour slot on this dance. The next spelldance you enter before the end of your next turn will grant you 2 additional vigour slots. This augment cannot be then used on that spelldance.

entries.name: Dance of the Spiral
entries: You can spend a vigour slot to generate a strong dust devil from you till the beginning of your next turn. A spherical area of 10 foot radius around you is difficult terrain for creatures besides you.

entries.name: Drunkard's Dance
entries: You can spend a vigour slot to gain +2 to your AC till the beginning of your next turn.

entries.name: Dance of the Coiled Serpent
entries: You can spend a vigour slot to extend your spelldance till the beginning of your next turn. While in this state you can cast Cantrips at any creature you can see that makes an attack roll without using your reaction provided it is in range of the Cantrip.

entries.name: Dance of Torn Mind
entries: You may spend no vigour slots to enter this dance. While this dance is in effect, you may cast two Cantrips that require concentration and hold concentration on both of them. Though for as long as you hold concentration on both of them, your choreurgic repletion suffers by 1 vigour slot.

entries.name: Vengeful Dance
entries: You may spend 2 vigour slots to enter a retaliatory state. Till the beginning of your next turn, Creatures that make an attack targeting you are marked till the end of your next turn. The first Cantrip cast at each of them will impose disadvantage for its saving throw.

classFeature.name: Art Feature
entries: At the 6th Level, You gain a feature granted by your Choreurgic Art.

classFeature.name: Fleet of Foot
entries: At the 7th Level, If you are affected by a spell that isn't targeting you, you can use your reaction to move 10 ft before it hits potentially avoiding damage. Additionally, While wearing light or no armour you gain 10 feet of movement.

classFeature.name: Persistence
entries: At the 5th Level, your cantrips count as 3rd level spells for the purposes of resisting the effects of {@spell counterspell} and {@spell dispel magic}. This feature improves as you gain levels in this class.
Counting as 4th level spells at the 11 level and 5th level spells at the 17 level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Depleted Casting
entries: At the 9th level, as a bonus action you can make all cantrips cast this turn more potent at the cost of power. Cantrips you cast on that turn will have advantage on their attack rolls and they impose disadvantage on saving throws at the cost of 1 damage die rolled from each cantrip cast.

classFeature.name: Art Feature
entries: At the 10th level, You gain a feature granted by your Choreurgic Art.

classFeature.name: Perpetual Motion
entries: At the 11th Level, you can get up from being {@condition prone} with only 5 feet of movement. Additionally, non-magical difficult terrain does not hinder your movement.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Elastic body
entries: At the 13th, You have advantage on all saving throws and checks to avoid or escape an effect that causes you to be grappled or restrained.

classFeature.name: Magic Resistance
entries: At the 13th, When subjected to a saving throw caused by a spell, you can spend a reaction to gain +5 bonus to the roll.

classFeature.name: Art Feature
entries: At the 14th level, You gain a feature granted by your Choreurgic Art.

classFeature.name: Supreme Tachyurgy
entries: At the 15th level, you can cast three cantrips, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action cast a spell} action on your turn.
Unless you have the Extra Attack feature, only one of those cantrips cast can involve a weapon attack, otherwise two of them may involve weapon attacks.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Omneurgist
entries: At the 17th level, You know all the cantrips that can be learnt by a wizard.

classFeature.name: Esoteric techniques
entries: At the 18th level, great effort and experimentation has allowed you to simplify basic spells down to a technique. Pick two level 1 spells from the wizard spell list. They are now Cantrips for you and won't count towards spells known.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM uses the optional Feats, you can instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Magnum Opus
entries: You've toiled away your entire life to reach here. A spell that takes most years to master cast, expressed in splendid motion.

At the 20th level, choose a {@filter spell of upto 5th level|spells|class=wizard|level=1;2;3;4;5} from the wizard spell list. This spell becomes your Magnum Opus. You may cast this spell as a Cantrip once per turn, a number of times equal to your Intelligence Modifier per day.

classFeature.name: Arcane Pioneer
entries: At 20th level, you begin to break down the barriers of your magic, gaining the ability to learn spells from outside your class.

You can add 6 spells from the {@filter from the sorcerer or warlock spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock|level=1;2;3;4;5;6;7;8;9} to your spellbook, and can have 6 additional spells prepared. You can further add spells from the two spell lists through spell scrolls, similar to how you would wizard spells.

classFeature.name: Pact Boon
entries: At 3rd level, your otherworldly patron bestows a gift upon you for your loyal service. You gain one of the following features of your choice.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Starting at 4th level, Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery property of three kinds of Simple or Martial weapons of your choice. Whenever you finish a Long rest, you can practice weapon drills and change one of those weapon choices.
Consult the {@table Weapons|tct} and {@table Weapon Masteries|tct} tables for information on masteries and their abilities.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Starting at 4th level, Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery property of three kinds of Simple or Martial weapons of your choice. Whenever you finish a Long rest, you can practice weapon drills and change one of those weapon choices.
Consult the {@table Weapons|tct} and {@table Weapon Masteries|tct} tables for information on masteries and their abilities.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Starting at 4th level, Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery property of three kinds of Simple or Martial weapons of your choice. Whenever you finish a Long rest, you can practice weapon drills and change one of those weapon choices.
Consult the {@table Weapons|tct} and {@table Weapon Masteries|tct} tables for information on masteries and their abilities.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Starting at 4th level, Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery property of three kinds of Simple or Martial weapons of your choice. Whenever you finish a Long rest, you can practice weapon drills and change one of those weapon choices.
Consult the {@table Weapons|tct} and {@table Weapon Masteries|tct} tables for information on masteries and their abilities.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Starting at 4th level, Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery property of three kinds of Simple or Martial weapons of your choice. Whenever you finish a Long rest, you can practice weapon drills and change one of those weapon choices.
Consult the {@table Weapons|tct} and {@table Weapon Masteries|tct} tables for information on masteries and their abilities.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Starting at 4th level, Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery property of three kinds of Simple or Martial weapons of your choice. Whenever you finish a Long rest, you can practice weapon drills and change one of those weapon choices.
Consult the {@table Weapons|tct} and {@table Weapon Masteries|tct} tables for information on masteries and their abilities.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 6th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. However, if you are atleast 19th level, that maximum increases to 22.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Master of Armaments
entries: You are a master of weapons. From 9th level, whenever you finish a Long Rest, you can choose any of the kinds of Mastery weaapons you're using and replace the Mastery property of each with another Mastery property. For examble, you could replace the Longsword's Sap property with the Push property.
These property changes apply only for you, not for others, and the changes end for you when you finish your next Long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 14th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. However, if you are atleast 19th level, that maximum increases to 22.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Secrets
entries: At 20th level, you begin unshackling the limits of Mystic Arcanum. Whenever you take a Short Rest, you can regain the use of one expended Mystic Arcanum.

classFeature.name: Rage
entries: In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.
While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren't wearing heavy armor:

items: You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

When you deal damage with a weapon attack using Strength, or take damage for the first time on a turn. you gain a charge of {@b Wrath}. The amount of wrath you have at any time cannot exceed your constitution modifier. Each charge of wrath is represented by your wrath die, as shown in the class table. You can use wrath in two ways, and you lose all existing stacks of wrath when you lose rage.

You can expend one charge of wrath to use your bonus action extend your rage for one turn if you failed to attack or take damage to maintain it. This feature cannot extend the rage's duration over a minute.
When you hit a creature with a weapon attack using strength, you can choose to expend all of your wrath charges and deal damage equal to the number rolled.

entries: If you are able to cast spells, you can't cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked {@condition unconscious} or if your turn ends and you haven't attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the maximum number of times for your barbarian level, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again. You may rage 2 times at 1st level, 3 at 3rd, 4 at 6th, 5 at 12th, and 6 at 17th.

classFeature.name: Reckless Attack
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using Strength until the start of your next turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.

classFeature.name: Primal Knowledge
entries: {@i 3rd-level barbarian}
When you reach 3rd level and again at 10th level, you gain proficiency in one skill of your choice from the list of skills available to barbarians at 1st level.

In addition, while your Rage is active, you can channel primal power when you attempt certain tasks; whenever you make an ability check using one of the following skills, you can make it as a Strength check even if it normally uses a different ability: {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Perception}, {@skill Stealth} or {@skill Survival}. When you use this ability, your Strength represents primal power coursing through you, honing your agility and senses.

classFeature.name: Brutal Critical
entries: Beginning at 9th level, your rage can give you occasional bursts of unfathomable power. When you land a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you take the maximum possible result on any damage die. Additionally, you can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for the critical hit with a melee attack.
This increases to two additional dice at 13th level and three additional dice at 17th level.

classFeature.name: Primal Champion
entries: At 20th level, you embody the power of the wilds. Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 26.

classFeature.name: Second Wind
entries: You have a limited well of stamina that you can draw on to protect yourself from harm. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to {@dice 1d10} + your fighter level.
You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses whenever you finish a long rest. You gain more uses of this feature, as shown in the Second Wind column of the Fighter table.

classFeature.name: Tactical Mind
entries: You have a mind for tactics and getting the upper hand on and off the battlefield. Beginning at 2nd level, whenever you fail an ability check, you can expend a use of your Second Wind to push yourself towards success.

Rather than regaining Hit Points,  you roll {@dice 1d10} and add the number rolled to the ability check, potentially turning it into a success. If the check still fails, this use of Second Wind isn't expended.

classFeature.name: Tactical Shift
entries: at 5th level, whenever you activate your Second Wind with a bonus action, you can move up to half your speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

classFeature.name: Indomitable
entries: Beginning at 9th level, you can reroll a saving throw that you fail with a bonus equal to your fighter level. If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.
You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 13th level.

classFeature.name: Weapon Adept (optional)
entries: You are a master of weapons. At 13th level, when you change the mastery property of your weapon, you can give that weapon two properties rather than one, being able to use the secondary property once per turn.
The secondary property you choose must also have its prerequisite satisfied by your weapon.

classFeature.name: Unconquerable
entries: When you're in great peril, you can tap into a deep well of resilience within yourself. Beginning at 18th level, If you fail a saving throw and your Indomitable feature is expended, you can use it again by expending a use of your Second Wind, which also heals you.

classFeature.name: Effortless Charm
entries: At 20th level, You can give out a Bardic Inspiration die to your allies at the start of your turn, rather than using a Bonus Action.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin
entries: Choose a sorcerous origin, which describes the source of your innate magical power, from the list of available origins.
Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level and again at 6th, 14th, and 18th level.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: An event in your past, or in the life of a parent or ancestor, left an indelible mark on you, infusing you with arcane magic. This font of magic, whatever its origin, fuels your spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|class=sorcerer}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. You learn an additional sorcerer cantrip of your choice at 4th level and another at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Sorcerer table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter sorcerer spells|spells|class=sorcerer} of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these sorcerer spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell burning hands} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell burning hands} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the sorcerer spell list.

You learn an additional sorcerer spell of your choice at each level except 12th, 14th, 16th, 18th, 19th, and 20th. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the sorcerer spells you know and replace it with another spell from the sorcerer spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, since the power of your magic relies on your ability to project your will into the world. You use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells.

classFeature.name: Flexible Casting
entries: You can use your sorcery points to gain additional spell slots, or sacrifice spell slots to gain additional sorcery points. You learn other ways to use your sorcery points as you reach higher levels.

entries.name: Creating Spell Slots
entries: You can transform unexpended sorcery points into one spell slot as a bonus action on your turn. The created spell slots vanish at the end of a long rest. The Creating Spell Slots table shows the cost of creating a spell slot of a given level. You can create spell slots no higher in level than 5th.

entries.name: Converting a Spell Slot to Sorcery Points
entries: As a bonus action on your turn, you can expend one spell slot and gain a number of sorcery points equal to the slot's level.

classFeature.name: Font of Magic
entries: At 2nd level, you tap into a deep wellspring of magic within yourself. This wellspring is represented by sorcery points, which allow you to create a variety of magical effects.

classFeature.name: Sorcery Points
entries: You have 2 sorcery points, and you gain one additional point every time you level up, to a maximum of 20 at level 20. You can never have more sorcery points than shown on the table for your level. You regain all spent sorcery points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the ability to twist your spells to suit your needs. You gain two of the following Metamagic options of your choice. You gain another one at 10th and 17th level.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted.

classFeature.name: Metamagic Options
entries: {@i 3rd-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}
When you choose Metamagic options, you have access to the following additional options.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. However, if you are atleast 19th level, that maximum increases to 22.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}
Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can do one of the following, representing the magic within you flowing in new ways:

items: Replace one of the options you chose for the Metamagic feature with a different {@filter Metamagic option|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=MM} available to you.
Replace one cantrip you learned from this class's Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|level=0|class=Sorcerer}.

classFeature.name: Magical Guidance
entries: {@i 5th-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}

You can tap into your inner wellspring of magic to try to conjure success from failure. When you make an ability check that fails, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll the {@dice d20}, and you must use the new roll, potentially turning the failure into a success.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. However, if you are atleast 19th level, that maximum increases to 22.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Innate Sorcery
entries: You discover a new wellspring of magic within you. As a bonus action, you can tap into that magic for 1 minute, during which you gain the following benefits:

items: The spell save DC of your sorcerer spells increases by 1.
You have advantage on spell attack rolls.

entries: You can use this feature once, regaining its use when you finish a long rest.
If you have run out of uses of this feature, you can instead spend 3 sorcery points to use this feature again.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 10th level, you learn an additional metamagic option.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. However, if you are atleast 19th level, that maximum increases to 22.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. However, if you are atleast 19th level, that maximum increases to 22.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 17th level, you learn an additional metamagic option.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 18th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. However, if you are atleast 19th level, that maximum increases to 22.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.
