The many princes, dukes  and merchant lords would come to find the saboteurs’ expertise invaluable in setting their competition back a few years.

entries.name: Saboteur
entries: The war is not yet over. All that has changed are the front lines.

subclassFeature.name: Saboteur Spells
entries: You always have certain spells prepared after you reach particular levels in this class, as shown in the Saboteur Spells table. These spells count as Artificer spells for you, but they don't count against the number of Artificer spells you prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: When you adopt this specialization at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item mason’s tools|phb} and {@item alchemist’s tools|phb}. If you already have either of these proficiencies, you gain proficiency with one other type of artisan's tools of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Third Arm
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to magically transform your {@item mason’s tools|phb} into a contraption that functions as a third arm. It functions like an arm that can wield weapons, shields, focii and other such things. Over a short rest, you can spend a spell slot to produce your third arm from your Mason’s Tools. While wielding it, it can be utilized as a set of Mason’s Tools and may perform the following.
While it is being used, your reach for actions using it increases by 5 feet. If the arm is not wielding anything you can use a bonus action to perform the following with it:-

entries.name: Slip Away
entries: The arm aids provides a distraction, allowing you to disengage

entries.name: Protect
entries: The arm readies into a defensive stance. Your AC increases as though wielding a shield and you recieve Temporary Hit Points equal to {@dice 1d8} + your Intelligence modifier. These benefits remain until the arm is used for something else.

entries.name: Repair
entries: (2/Day). The hands innate magic restores {@dice 2d8} + PB hit points to one construct or object within 5 feet of it.

entries.name: Dodge
entries: The arm anticipates any attack made against it. You gain the benefits of a Dodge action.

entries.name: Help
entries: You or another creature within the arm's reach gains the benefit of a help action. When done this way, it does not grant advantage on skill checks.
If a bonus action wasn’t used to activate it and isn’t wielding anything, it will automatically perform the dodge action, Any attack directed at it instead goes to you.

You may determine the arms appearance when you create it. It consists of a base that is worn on your body and the appendage which may range in appearance as an arm with many joints, to a tentacle resembling a spine, to a floating claw.

subclassFeature.name: Apprentice Arsonist
entries: At 3rd level, Your knowledge in volatile alchemy has granted you the ability to create Bombs. Using your Alchemist’s Tools you may create a number of them equal to your proficiency bonus during a short or long rest. Creating more than that will result in the oldest bomb turning inert and disintegrating. Bombs that are not on your person begin to decay and will too turn inert and disintegrate after a days time has passed.
While you possess these bombs, you may use an action to throw them upto 20 feet away after which they will explode on impact, affecting creatures in a spherical area.
When you create the bombs you can determine its type from the the following

entries.name: Fireworks
entries: Subjects Creatures in a 15 foot radius to a Dexterity Saving Throw. Deals {@damage 3d10} Fire Damage on a failure.

entries.name: Sunburst
entries: Subjects creatures in a 10 foot radius to a Constitution Saving Throw. Deals {@damage 3d8} Radiant Damage and {@condition blinded|phb|blinds} them on a failure.

entries.name: Impellors
entries: Subjects creatures in a 20 foot radius to a Strength Saving Throw. Deals {@damage 3d8} Thunder Damage and throws them back 10 foot on a failure.

entries.name: Box of Nox
entries: Subjects creatures in a 10 feet radius to a Constitution Saving Throw. Deals {@damage 4d4} Poison Damage and they become {@condition poisoned}.

entries.name: Canned Fog
entries: Produces the {@spell Fog Cloud} Spell Effect at the point of impact.

entries.name: Wurmbite
entries: Subjects creatures in a 20 feet radius to a Dexterity Saving Throw. Deals {@damage 4d6} Acid Damage and another {@damage 2d6} on the start of its turn on a failure and half as much on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 5th level, you can attack twice, rather than once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. You may replace of one of the attacks, with the throw of a bomb.

items: The reach of your arm increases by a further 5 feet and you can cast spells from your Third Arm and while it is not wielding anything, you gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.

When a bomb damages an object that isn’t being worn or carried, depending on the material of the object and the bomb used, it deals critical damage. For dirt and/or stone; an Impeller, For Metal; a Wurmbite and For wood; a Fireworks.

subclassFeature.name: Explosives Expert
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can increase the potency of your explosives.

items: You can throw you bombs upto 60 feet away.
Your Bombs deal an additional dice of damage of its damage type if it can deal damage.

You gain the ability to plant bombs and explode them remotely. When you use a bomb to interact with an object, you may affix the bomb to it given that it is not being worn or carried. You may then set a timer for when it explodes (Remember that a bomb may become inert after a days time from creation has passed). Or you may activate one of your choice with a bonus action. A bomb that is damaged by another bomb will automatically explode.

subclassFeature.name: Pyrotechnic Pandemonium
entries: Starting at 15th level, Once you breach the enemy’s lines, you turn into the very spirit of chaos.

items: On your first round of combat, you can utilize your arms functions using a free action

Once per short/long rest, You can use a bonus action to throw 3 grenades with your third arm. Creatures affected must also make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a creature becomes frightened of you for 1 minute. The frightened creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Congregation
entries: Though realms, kingdoms and empires may span the world treading over swathes of environments in the process, the dwellings they create over it are not devoid of natural power. In the creation of cities, towns and village, a conduit of nature has not been removed but changed. As such, some circles of druids form for settlements, controlling and cultivating their growth either for its own sake or to entwine it with nature.

Druids of this Circle harbour a respect for the design of the settlements under their care, the weaving of flora into it as well as the wellbeing of the creatures, both humanoid and not. In this pursuit they become counsel to governers, rulers and architects and usually become amicable members of the soceities they develop.
These druids work tirelessly towards achieving harmony between animal, person, and plant life of their settlement and many have prospered for it.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your time working with the nature within civilization grants you access to certain spells. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of Congregation Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency in {@skill Insight}. You also gain proficiency in {@skill Persuasion} and you can make it's checks with Wisdom instead of Charisma.

subclassFeature.name: One of Many
entries: Your ties with the settlements extends to its littlest denizens. As a bonus action, You can expend a use of wildhsape to summon a Swarm within 30 feet of you. A Swarm comprises of tiny spectral creatures that you can wildshape into. They seem real to an untrained eye but a creature can use its action to inspect its appearance and must succeed on an {@skill Investigation} check against your spell save DC revealing them to be spectral.

They occupy a circular area 10 feet wide on the ground and last for an hour before dissipating. The Swarm has a health of 5 + 5 times your level as a druid. While you are in the Swarm's space, you may wildshape into a creature of the Swarm as a bonus action without expending a use of it but you reduce the health of the Swarm by 5 doing so. You may also do so as part of the same action taken to summon the Swarm.
As a bonus action you may choose to command the Swarm to move, moving upto 30 feet horizontally. It may also climb walls.
When creating a Swarm choose one of the following forms. It gains the benefits associated with it:-

items: {@b Flurry}: As part of it's command, it attacks all creatures present within the Swarm's space. Once during its command, make a spell attack against each target within, dealing force damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + your Wisdom modifier on a hit. Once per round, you may make this attack against a creature attempting to leave the Swarm's area.

{@b Scurry}: The Swarm's space acts as magical difficult terrain for creatures of your choice. When it moves, you can choose to move willing creatures standing within along with the Swarm. They move upto 15 feet this way.

{@b Blurry}: A friendly creature standing within the Swarm benefits from half cover for ranged attacks and is lightly obscured. Once per round, if a creature within the Swarm's space takes damage from an attack, you may choose to reduce the damage by half but must also reduce the Swarm's health by the same amount.

subclassFeature.name: Agent of Peace
entries: Your understanding of the congreagation has deepened allowing you to better communicate and coordinate. You permanently gain the benefit of {@spell speak with animals}.
In addition your Swarm can exist and travel in bodies of water. When summoning a Swarm in said body, it occupies a spherical area upto 20 feet wide or a circular area upto 20 feet wide on the ground.

subclassFeature.name: Emissary of Order
entries: You exude an aura of comradery for your companions. While within 30 feet of you they may spend a bonus action to steel themselves, granting them temporary hitpoints equal to your level as a druid. They also receive a {@dice 1d6|d6} that they may spend to add to a skill check or saving throw that they make. The die and the temporary hit points disappear after a minute. Once gained, they must take a short rest to recieve this benefit again.
You Swarm can now incorporate avian creatures, granting it the ability to fly. A Swarm can now be summoned at a point in the air and can be moved in any direction.

subclassFeature.name: Ambassador of Harmony
entries: You have become a master at communication and resolution. When making checks with {@skill Insight} or {@skill Persuasion} you may now add twice your proficiency bonus to them.
You can now coordinate a swarm of upto 30 feet in width. When you command the swarm, it may now move upto 45 feet and you receive the following benefits depending on the type of swarm youve summoned.

items: {@b Flurry}: The damage die icreases to {@damage 3d4}. When the swarm moves it deals {@damage 2d4} force damage when moving into a creatures space. It may only deal this damage once per creature on this turn.
{@b Scurry}: Creatures moving along with the swarm now can move upto 30 feet. A creature moved into the air now hovers till it uses it's movement speed.

{@b Blurry}: A friendly creature standing within the Swarm benefits from three-fourths cover from ranged attacks and may attempt to hide within. While inside they can take the {@action Disengage} action as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Bloodcursed
entries: Not all plants grow where they should, not all animals graze where they live, not all environments thrive. Druids from the circle of the Sanguine view themselves as crusaders against that belief.

Hailing or beginning from places where the balance of nature has already been broken, they take on a much more extreme approach to the preservation of their grove, emphasizing on sacrfice and early aggression. Reflecting this, they allow for the practice of necromancy and other abilities involving the transfer of vitality between the environment and its denizens.
Whether out of desperation or fanaticism, they are highly protective and have come to embody the turbulent battleground of their grove.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: By tapping into the essence in blood and it's primal power, you and your kin unlock it's potential. At 2nd level, you learn the {@spell primal savagery|xge} cantrip. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Bloodcursed Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Primal Form
entries: Through self control and the circle's teachings you have learnt to draw from your blood your hidden nature. You may expend a use of wildshape as a bonus action to transform into a Hybrid Form. Choose a creature that you can wildshape into, you can choose to gain the following from it:-

items: Any actions it can do except for Multiattack. If it is an attack, you may replace the attack and damage modifiers with your Wisdom modifier.
Its Hit Points as Temporary Hit Points.
Its size (but only as high as large and as small as small)
It's AC as Natural Armour and a bonus to it equal to your Constitution modifier if using it.
Any abilities the beast possesses.

entries: While you have temporary hitpoints from this feature you may use an action to wild shape fully into the creature without expending a use of Wild Shape but replacing the hit points with the temporary hit points. You revert to Primal Form from Wild Shape if you use a bonus action to do so or if you drop to 0 hit points, transferring any health remaining as temporary hit points.

The rules for the duration, dismissal and reverting of Wild Shape apply to Primal Form as well. You may extend the duration of your Primal From and/or change it by expending another use of Wild Shape as a bonus action which also restores temporary hit points to the chosen beast's hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Advanced Therianthropy
entries: Your blood holds secrets greater than you know, but you've yet come a long way in realizing it. You gain addtional benefits to your primal form:-

items: If a beast possesses the Multiattack feature, you may now use it. Additionally, attacks with your natural weapons count as magical for the purposes of overcoming resistances.
You gain it's movement speeds upto a limit of 40 feet. This limit improves to 50 feet at level 14 in this class.
You receive any of the chosen beast's  proficiencies.
You receive any of the chosen beast's senses.

subclassFeature.name: Restorative Blood
entries: As part of a use of Primal Form you may allow your flesh to knit itself back together. Upon activation and at the start of each of your turns for a minute, you regain hit points equal to your Constitution modifier. This effect ends prematurely if you drop to 0 hit points. You regain use of this feature after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Therianthrope Supreme
entries: By achieving the perfect fusion of bestial nature, you've drawn the full potential of your moon-touched blood. You gain the following benefits:-

items: You have advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effect effects.
You are immune to any spells or effects that would alter your form against your will.
You can Wild Shape into CR 2 beasts now and CR 3 beasts at level 18.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Sanguine
entries: Not all plants grow where they should, not all animals graze where they live, not all environments thrive. Druids from the circle of the Sanguine view themselves as crusaders against that belief.

Hailing or beginning from places where the balance of nature has already been broken, they take on a much more extreme approach to the preservation of their grove, emphasizing on sacrfice and early aggression. Reflecting this, they allow for the practice of necromancy and other abilities involving the transfer of vitality between the environment and its denizens.
Whether out of desperation or fanaticism, they are highly protective and have come to embody the turbulent battleground of their grove.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your practices and study regarding the flux of vitality grants you access to certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the {@spell transfusion|tct} cantrip. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Sanguine Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Sanguine Spells
rows: {@spell aura of life}, {@spell guardian of nature|xge}

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Arms
entries: Sanguine rites demand the letting of vitality from sacrifices willing or otherwise. As such they have adopted and utilize certain weapons as part of their rituals and spells. As a sanguine druid, you utilize {@item dagger|tct|daggers}, {@item sickle|tct|sickles}, {@item bill|tct|bills or scythes}. They count as Sanguine weapons for you.
They act as arcane focuses and at the 10th level of this class, they deal an additional {@damage 1d6} damage.
Additionally, though they show reluctance, Sanguine druids can wear armours and shields made of metal.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Fury
entries: You channel your fervor into righteous fury. As a bonus action, you may expend a use of you beast shape to enter a state of heightened ability. While in this state you recieve the following beneifts:-

items: You are not affected by difficult terrain.
When using Sanguine Weapons, you can use your Wisdom modifier in place of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls and you can change the weapons damage to necrotic.
You gain a bonus to concentration saves equal to your Wisdom modifer.

When you use an action or a bonus action to cast a spell, you can immediately use your bonus action or action (respectively) to make a melee attack with a Sanguine weapon you are wielding before the spell is fully cast as though you do it part of the casting. If the attack hits, you may roll an additional die when rolling for the damage or healing done by the spell. If the attack is a critical hit, you may roll another die. If you die or fall {@condition unconscious} before the spell is cast, the spell is lost.

entries: It ends early if you dismiss it (no action required), are {@condition incapacitated} or die.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. This applies to when you use your action to make a sanguine fury attack as well, improving the spell if any attack hits or lands critically.

subclassFeature.name: Vital Inheritance
entries: When a creature dies within 30 feet of you, you may use your reaction to drain its essence, healing a willing target within 30 feet for a number of hitpoints equal to your druid level + Your Wisdom modifier.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Earth to Earth
entries: At the 10th level, You learn the {@spell plant growth} spell. It doesn't count against the number of Druid spells you know and you receive a special way to cast it.

Instead of using a spell slot you can touch a corpse of a creature of CR3 or higher that has died in the past 24 hours. The corpse turns to ash at the end of the casting and if using the immediate effects of the spell, the plants only grow in an area of upto 50 feet in radius, but you move through them without needing extra movement while in Sanguine fury.
You may instead at the end of the immediate casting, produce a tree upto 40 feet tall and upto 10 feet thick in diameter.

subclassFeature.name: Sentinel of Nature
entries: At the 14th level, you learn to turn your enemies into the very defenders of what they seek to destroy. You know the {@spell summon undead|tce} spell and it doesn't count against the number of Druid spells you know and you receive a special way to cast it.

Instead of its normal material component, you may touch a corpse of a creature of CR3 or higher that has died in the past 24 hours. When cast this way, the corpse disintegrates and the spell cast requires no concentration and lasts until being dispelled. Casting this spell again destroys any undead spirits from a previous casting.
You may only cast this way again after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Fortune
entries: Rogues of Fortune are seemingly blessed. When a guard turns a corner, he finds himself distracted. When playing a game of dice, his opponent procures a pair of snake eyes. When rummaging for loot, they 'happen' upon a few gems in a hidden container.
Mayhaps they unknowingly possess some patron deity bestowing favor upon them or they have a knack for knowing just the right odds to win or they were born under some fortunate sign.
Whatever the reason may be, they are lucky and they dodge misfortune with unwitting ease. At least, until their luck runs out...

subclassFeature.name: High Roller
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item gaming set||gaming sets} and the bonus is doubled when you make checks with it.

subclassFeature.name: Golden Luck
entries: You fortune has culminated with your possession of a 'golden' Luck die. It is a {@dice 1d20|d20} that you may spend to reroll {@dice 1d20|d20} checks.

In function, it works like a luck point from the {@feat lucky} feat, becoming 'copper' when used. While so, you may spend it again, but doing so 'burns' it only becoming 'golden' again after a long rest.

While it is copper and not burnt, you may turn it golden by taking a short or long rest, or silver by rolling a natural 20 as part of an ability check, saving throw or attack roll turns the die 'silver' which functions like gold for a minute, but decaying to copper again at the end.
When you roll for initiative, any copper die turn silver.
You may also spend a luck die before making an attack to grant advantage to it (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Lucky Shot
entries: When rolling sneak damage, If any sneak die roll a 6, roll an additional {@damage 1d6|d6} and add it to the damage.

subclassFeature.name: Twister of Fate
entries: At the 9th level, When a creature you see within 60 feet of you rolls a 20 for an attack roll, skill check or saving throw you can force them to reroll. You can do this a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus.
Additionally, if you have a copper die when this is done it, becomes silver for a minute.

subclassFeature.name: Against all Odds
entries: When rolling an attack roll, skill check or saving throw at disadvantage, you may spend your luck die to roll with advantage instead.

subclassFeature.name: Expected Outcomes
entries: At the 13th level, When you spend your luck die, you may forgo the roll entirely to roll a 10 on it.

subclassFeature.name: Opportunist
entries: When a creature within 60 feet of you rolls a natural 1 on an attack roll, saving throw or ability check. It is marked by you and remains so until the end of your turn. When you make an attack against a marked creature, you may spend a luck die and treat the attack roll result as a 20.

subclassFeature.name: Cannoneer
entries: A Cannoneer specializes in combining magic and artifice to effortlessly create weapons of war. Known to be the product of artisanal, industrial or arcane civilizations, they were highly sought after for the chaos they wrought upon armies. To this day soldiers still suffer of their use on the battlefield.

subclassFeature.name: Cannoneer Spells
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have certain spells prepared after you reach particular levels in this class, as shown in the Cannoneer Spells table. These spells count as artificer spells for you, but they don't count against the number of artificer spells you prepare.

entries.caption: Cannoneer Spells
rows: {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell wall of force}

subclassFeature.name: Eldritch Cannon
entries: At 3rd level, you learn how to create a magical cannon. Using {@item woodcarver's tools|phb} or {@item smith's tools|phb}, you can take an action to magically create a Small or Tiny eldritch cannon in an unoccupied space on a horizontal surface within 5 feet of you. A Small eldritch cannon occupies its space, and a Tiny one can be held in one hand.

Once you create a cannon, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest or until you expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher. You can have only one cannon at a time and can't create one while your cannon is present.

The cannon is a magical object. Regardless of size, the cannon has an AC of 18 and a number of hit points equal to five times your artificer level. It is immune to poison damage and psychic damage, and all conditions. If it is forced to make an ability check or a saving throw, treat all its ability scores as 10 (+0). If the {@spell mending} spell is cast on it, it regains {@dice 2d6} hit points. It disappears if it is reduced to 0 hit points or after 1 hour. You can dismiss it early as an action.

When you create the cannon, you determine its appearance and whether it has legs. You also decide which type it is, choosing from the options on the Eldritch Cannons table. On each of your turns, you can take a bonus action to cause the cannon to activate if you are within 60 feet of it. As part of the same bonus action, you can direct the cannon to walk or climb up to 15 feet to an unoccupied space, provided it has legs. You may also make it fire by taking the Attack action, replacing the weapon attack in the process.

While you are holding a Tiny cannon, you may use it as an arcane focus for your artificer spells.  When you cast an artificer spell through the firearm, roll a {@damage d8}, and you gain a bonus to one of the spell's damage rolls equal to the number rolled.

entries.caption: Eldritch Cannons
rows: The cannon exhales fire in an adjacent 15-foot cone that you designate. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 2d8} fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire ignites any flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

Make a ranged spell attack, originating from the cannon, at one creature or object within 120 feet of it. On a hit, the target takes force damage equal to {@damage 1d8} + your Intelligence Modifier , and if the target is a creature, it is pushed up to 5 feet away from the cannon.

The cannon launches a shell at a point you designate within 30 feet. It explodes causing each creature within 10 feet of the point to make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 2d8} Thunder damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a success.

The cannon projects a beacon 20 feet long, creatures in its path must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 2d8} radiant damage on a failure or half as much on a success

The cannon casts a translucent field of abjuring magic which has a pool of hitpoints equal to 5 times your artificer level. When a creature or object stands within 10 feet of the protector and receives damage, you can choose to reduce the pools HP by an amount you choose instead, with the target taking any remaining damage. When activated, the pool replenishes by {@damage 2d8} + your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1).

subclassFeature.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: When you adopt this specialization at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item woodcarver's tools|phb} or {@item smiths's tools|phb}. If you already have both these proficiencies, you gain proficiency with one other type of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Battery
entries: At 5th level, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn, you may additionally fire from your Eldritch Cannon as part of the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Eldritch Salvo
entries: Starting at 9th level, every eldritch cannon you create is more destructive, dealing an additional {@damage 1d8} damage and gaining the ability to launch a devastating attack. As an action, you may command your cannon to launch a salvo. The cannon may move and climb upto 30 feet as part of this command and launch the effect listed in the table below depending on the cannon.

entries.caption: Eldritch Cannons
rows: The cannon exhales fire in an adjacent 45-foot cone that you designate. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 6d8} fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire creeps around  ignites any flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

The cannon launches a barrage of 3 attacks. Make a ranged spell attack against upto 3 different creatures or objects within 120 feet of the cannon. On a hit, the target takes force damage equal to {@damage 6d8} force damage, and if the targets are creatures, they are pushed up to 15 feet away from the cannon.

The cannon launches a massive shell at a point you designate within 90 feet. It explodes causing each creature within 30 feet of the point to make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 6d8} Thunder damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a success.

The cannon energizes a beam 60 feet long, creatures in its path must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 6d8} radiant damage on a failure or half as much on a success

The cannon rapidly regenerates its shield for {@damage 6d8} hit points and till the beginning of your next turn, extends it reach upto 30 feet. and for each 2 hitpoints absorbed, the pool only reduces by 1. (Variant. 1st instance of damage above 10 points is halved),

subclassFeature.name: Fortified Position
entries: Starting at 15th level, you're a master at forming well-defended emplacements using Eldritch Cannon:

items: You and your allies have half cover while within 10 feet of a cannon you create with Eldritch Cannon, as a result of a shimmering field of magical protection that the cannon emits.

You can now have two cannons at the same time. You can create two with the same action (but not the same spell slot), and you can activate both of them with the same bonus action. You determine whether the cannons are identical to each other or different. You can't create a third cannon while you have two.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemist
entries: An Alchemist is an expert at combining reagents to produce mystical effects. Alchemists use their creations to give life and to leech it away. Alchemy is the oldest of artificer traditions, and its versatility has long been valued during times of war and peace.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemist Spells
entries: {@i 3rd-level Alchemist feature}

You always have certain spells prepared after you reach particular levels in this class, as shown in the Alchemist Spells table. These spells count as artificer spells for you, but they don't count against the number of artificer spells you prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Experimental Potion
entries: {@i 3rd-level Alchemist feature}

Creating a potion requires you to have {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB} on your person, and any potion you create with this feature lasts until it is drunk or until the end of your next long rest. As a bonus action, a creature can drink the elixir or administer it to a willing creature within 5 feet of it.

You can create additional Potions by expending a spell slot. When you do so, you use your action to create the elixir in an empty flask you touch, and you choose the potion's effect from the corresponding potion table.
If you drink a potion or elixir that you created, its effectiveness is improved, as shown in the brackets.
You can create two Experimental potions of your choice at the end of a long rest.

entries.caption: Experimental Potions
rows: {@b Healing}. The drinker regains a number of hit points equal to {@dice 2d4} + your Intelligence modifier (add your artificer level to the healing).
{@b Swiftness}. The drinker's walking speed increases by 10 feet for 1 hour (your speed is increased by 20 feet).
{@b Robust}. The drinker gains a +1 bonus to Ability checks, AC and saving throws for 10 minutes (the bonus is increased to +2).
{@b Boldness}. The drinker can roll a {@dice d4} and add the number rolled to every attack roll and saving throw they make for the next minute (The bonus is increased to  {@dice d8}).
{@b Flight}. The drinker gains a flying speed of 20 feet for 10 minutes (You gain a flying speed of 40 ft.).

{@b Transformation}. The drinker's body is transformed as if by the {@spell alter self} spell. The drinker determines the transformation caused by the spell, the effects of which last for 10 minutes (You can choose to gain any number of the benefits of the alter self spell).

subclassFeature.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: {@i 3rd-level Alchemist feature}
You gain proficiency with {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency with one other type of {@item artisan's tools|PHB} of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemical Savant
entries: At 5th level, you develop masterful command of magical chemicals, enhancing the healing and damage you create through them.

subclassFeature.name: Refined Formulae
entries: {@i 5th-level Alchemist feature}

Whenever you cast a spell using your {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB} as the spellcasting focus, you gain a bonus to one roll of the spell. That roll must restore hit points or be a damage roll that deals acid, fire, necrotic, or poison damage, and the bonus equals your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1).

Additionally, you gain the ability to brew more potent but less endurable potions. If a creature attempts to drink multiple refined potions which have a duration, it will only gain the benefit of the latest one. You can now also administer your potion to any creature within 30 feet of you.
You can create two Refined Potions of your choice at the end of a long rest

entries.caption: Refined Potions
rows: {@b Heroism}. The drinker regains a number of temporary hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier at the start of each of their turns. Additionally, it gains immunity to the {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} conditions. This benefit lasts for 1 minute (Any wasted temporary hitpoints are turned into healing).

{@b Speed}. While the potion is active, the drinker can make an additional weapon attack whenever they take the {@action Attack} action (You gain an additional action similar to the {@spell haste} spell).

{@b Mobile}. The drinker's movement speed is doubled for 1 minute. During that time, opportunity attacks made against the drinker are made at disadvantage (Your movement does not proc opportunity attacks).
{@b Resistance}. when the potion is used, The drinker gains resistance to a damage type of their choosing for 1 hour (You can choose two damage types when you drink the potion).

{@b Colossus}. The drinker's size increases by 1 level. Additionally, its weapons deal an additional {@dice 1d8} damage against creatures whose size is equal to or smaller than the drinker. (Your size increases by two levels, and the damage bonus is increased to {@dice 1d12}).
{@b Hill Giant}. The drinker's Strength score is increased to 21 for 1 hour (Your strength score is increased to 23).

subclassFeature.name: Armament Coatings
entries: You can create coatings that magically enhance the effectiveness of mundane weapons.
The coatings can only be applied to non-magical weapons or weapons turned magical by artificer infusions or spells such as {@spell magic weapon} or {@spell elemental weapon}.
A weapon can only gain the benefit of one coating at a time. The coatings last for 1 minute, and takes a bonus action to apply to a weapon.

entries.caption: Coatings (2nd level spell slot)
rows: {@b Sharpness}. The weapon gains a +1 bonus to its attack and damage rolls.
{@b Accuracy}. The weapon gains a +2 bonus to its attack rolls.

{@b Slaying}. Choose a creature type when you create this coating. The weapon gains an additional {@dice 2d6} damage against the creature. Additionally, any damage dealt by the coated weapons attack ignores damage resistances against the chosen creature type.

{@b Gleaming}. The weapon gains a +1 bonus to its damage rolls. Additionally, it emits an aura of bright light for 10 feet, and dim light for an additional 10 feet. As a reaction after being hit by an attack, the wielder can use their reaction to blind the attacker unless they make a constitution save against your spell save dc.
{@b Bane}. If the weapon lands an attack on a creature, the creature has a {@dice 1d4} penalty on its next attack roll or saving throw.
{@b Viciousness}. The roll required to land a critical hit while wielding this weapon is reduced by one.

subclassFeature.name: Restorative Reagents
entries: {@i 9th-level Alchemist feature}
You can incorporate restorative reagents into some of your works:

subclassFeature.name: Soothing Balm
entries: You can cast {@spell lesser restoration} without expending a spell slot and without preparing the spell, provided you use {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB} as the spellcasting focus. You can do so a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Experimental Elixir
entries: You have learnt to produce more durable and effective kinds of potions, which last until the end of a long rest.
Once a creature consumes an elixir, they cannot benefit from another elixir until they finish a long rest.
You can create two Experimental elixirs of your choice at the end of a long rest.

entries.caption: Experimental Elixirs
rows: {@b Bloodlust}. At any point after the elixir is used, the drinker can activate its magic, gaining an additional action during that turn. Once its property has been used, it cannot be used again until the drinker takes a Short Rest (You regain the use of this feature whenever you roll initiative).
{@b Arcane Cultivation}. The drinker gains an additional 5th spell slot (You gain a 6th level spell slot).

{@b Focus}. If the drinker fails a constitution saving throw in order to maintain concentration on a spell, they can choose to succeed instead. They can choose to do so a number of times equal to the alchemist's Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

{@b Cleansing}. The drinker gains the ability to shrug off the gravest of wounds. If you are affected by any of the conditions affected by the {@spell lesser restoration} and {@spell greater restoration}, as well as the {@condition stunned} or {@condition incapacitated} conditions, you can choose to end one of those conditions on you at the start of your turn. Once you cleanse any of those conditions, you cannot do so again until 10 minutes pass.

{@b Drake}. After drinking the potion, the creature can use its bonus action on any subsequent turn to exhale a 30-foot cone or a 60 foot line of damaging breath. Choose acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder or poison damage (your choice). Each creature in its area must make a dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@dice 4d8} damage on a failed save, or half as much on a succesful one. Once the breath is used, you cannot use it again unless it is recharged. The breath recharges when you Roll a 6 on a {@dice d6} at the start of your turn (The damage increases to {@dice 6d8} for you).

{@b Vigilant}. The drinker can't be {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} while they are conscious, and they gain advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks. Once before the elixir ends, you can give yourself a +10 bonus to an Initiative roll (you can give yourself the initiative bonus twice).

subclassFeature.name: Chemical Mastery
entries: {@i 15th-level Alchemist feature}
You have been exposed to so many chemicals that they pose little risk to you, and you can use them to quickly end certain ailments:

items: You gain resistance to acid damage and poison damage, and you are immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition.

You can cast {@spell greater restoration} and {@spell heal} without expending a spell slot, without preparing the spell, and without material components, provided you use {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB} as the spellcasting focus. Once you cast either spell with this feature, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a long rest. If you cast the spells on a creature other than yourself, you can gain the benefits of that spell as well.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Berserker
entries: For some barbarians, rage is a means to an end—that end being violence. The Path of the Berserker is a path of untrammeled fury, slick with blood. As you enter the berserker's rage, you thrill in the chaos of battle, heedless of your own health or well-being.

subclassFeature.name: Frenzy
entries: {@i 3rd-level Berserker feature}

You go into a frenzy when in battle. If you use reckless attack while your rage is active, you can deal extra damage to the first target you hit on your turn with a Strength-based attack. The extra damage is {@dice 2d6} at level three, and increases by {@dice 1d6} whenever your Wrath die scales.

subclassFeature.name: Mindless Rage
entries: {@i 6th-level Berserker feature}

You have immunity to the {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} conditions while your Rage is active. If you are {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} when you enter your rage, that condition ends on you.

subclassFeature.name: Retaliation
entries: {@i 10th-level Berserker feature}
When you take damage from a creature that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to make one melee weapon attack against that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Intimidating Presence
entries: {@i 14th-level Berserker feature}

You can strike terror into others with your menacing presence as you swell with primal power as a bonus action. When you do so, each creature that you can see within 30 feet of you, or 60 feet of you if you are raging must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier), provided the creature isn't behind total cover. On a failed save, a creature has the {@condition frightened} condition for 1 minute. At the end of each of the creature's turns, the creature repeats the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a successful save.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. If you've run out of uses of this feature, you can expend a use of your rage, choosing to activate intimidation presence instead of rage.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Shield
entries: {@i 6th-level Ancestral Guardian feature}

The guardian spirits that aid you can provide supernatural protection to those you defend. If you are raging and another creature you can see within 30 feet of you takes damage, you can use your reaction to reduce that damage by {@dice 2d6}. You can expend and roll any number of your wrath charges to further reduce the damage dealt.
When you reach certain levels in this class, you can reduce the damage by more: by {@dice 3d6} at 10th level and by {@dice 4d6} at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Consult the Spirits
entries: {@i 10th-level Ancestral Guardian feature}
You gain the ability to consult with your ancestral spirits. You gain the following features.

items: You gain the ability to cast the {@spell augury} or {@spell clairvoyance} spell, without using a spell slot or material components. Rather than creating a spherical sensor, this use of {@spell clairvoyance} invisibly summons one of your ancestral spirits to the chosen location. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells. After you cast either spell in this way, you can't use this feature again until you finish a short or long rest.
Your Ancestral Protectors feature now applies on every attack you make while raging, rather than the first one on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Storm Herald
entries: {@i 6th-level Ancestral Guardian feature}

All barbarians harbor a fury within. Their rage grants them superior strength, durability, and speed. Barbarians who follow the Path of the Storm Herald learn to transform that rage into a mantle of primal magic, which swirls around them. When in a fury, a barbarian of this path taps into the forces of nature to create powerful magical effects.

Storm heralds are typically elite champions who train alongside druids, rangers, and others sworn to protect nature. Other storm heralds hone their craft in lodges in regions wracked by storms, in the frozen reaches at the world's end, or deep in the hottest deserts.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Aura
entries: {@i 3rd-level Storm Herald feature}
You emanate a stormy, magical aura while you rage. The aura extends 10 feet from you in every direction, but not through total cover.

Your aura has an effect that activates when you enter your rage, and you can activate the effect again on each of your turns as a bonus action. Choose desert, sea, or tundra. Your aura's effect depends on that chosen environment, as detailed below. You can change your environment choice whenever you enter rage.
If your aura's effects require a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Desert
entries: When this effect is activated, creatures of your choice in your aura each take fire damage equal to 1 roll of your Wrath die. The damage increases when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to 2 rolls at 6th level  and 3 rolls at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Sea
entries: When this effect is activated, you can choose one other creature you can see in your aura. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw. The target takes {@damage 2d6} lightning damage on a failed save and cannot take reactions until the start of your next turn, or half as much damage on a successful one. The damage increases when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to {@dice 3d6} at 6th level, {@dice 4d6} at 14th level, and {@dice 5d6} at 20th level.

subclassFeature.name: Tundra
entries: When this effect is activated, each creature of your choice in your aura gains  temporary hit points equal to 1 roll of your Wrath die, as icy spirits inure it to suffering. The temporary hit points increase when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to 2 rolls at 6th level and 3 rolls at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Soul
entries: {@i 6th-level Storm Herald feature}
The storm grants you benefits even when your aura isn't active. The benefits are based on the environment you chose for your Storm Aura.

subclassFeature.name: Desert
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage, and you don't suffer the effects of extreme heat, as described in the Dungeon Master's Guide. Moreover, as an action, you can touch a flammable object that isn't being worn or carried by anyone else and set it on fire.

subclassFeature.name: Sea
entries: You gain resistance to lightning and Thunder damage, and you can breathe underwater. You also gain a swimming speed of 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Tundra
entries: You gain resistance to cold damage, and you don't suffer the effects of extreme cold, as described in the Dungeon Master's Guide. Moreover, as an action, you can touch water and turn a 5-foot cube of it into ice, which melts after 1 minute. This action fails if a creature is in the cube.

subclassFeature.name: Shielding Storm
entries: {@i 10th-level Storm Herald feature}
You learn to use your mastery of the storm to protect others. Each creature of your choice has the damage resistance you gained from the Storm Soul feature while the creature is in your Storm Aura.

Additionally, Whenever you gain a wrath charge from taking damage, you can choose to use a reaction and immediately expend the charge, activating the effects of the aura you have selected at the moment.

subclassFeature.name: Raging Storm
entries: {@i 14th-level Storm Herald feature}
The power of the storm you channel grows mightier, lashing out at your foes. The effect is based on the environment you chose for your Storm Aura.
Additionally, you can change your aura whenever you activate it with your bonus action, rather than whenever you rage.

subclassFeature.name: Desert
entries: Immediately after a creature in your aura hits you with an attack, you can force that creature to make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes fire damage equal to half your barbarian level.

subclassFeature.name: Sea
entries: When you hit a creature in your aura with an attack, you can force that creature to make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is knocked {@condition prone}, as if struck by a wave.

subclassFeature.name: Tundra
entries: Whenever the effect of your Storm Aura is activated, you can choose one creature you can see in the aura. That creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw, or its speed is reduced to 0 until the start of your next turn, as magical frost covers it.

subclassFeature.name: Fanatical Focus
entries: {@i 6th-level Zealot feature}

The divine power that fuels your rage can protect you. If you fail a saving throw while you're raging, you can expend a wrath charge to reroll it with a bonus to the saving throw equal to the number rolled on the wrath die. If this causes you to succeed the save, you cannot use this feature again during this rage.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Beast
entries: Barbarians who walk the Path of the Beast draw their rage from a bestial spark burning within their souls. That beast bursts forth in the throes of rage, physically transforming the barbarian.
Such a barbarian might be inhabited by a primal spirit or be descended from shape-shifters. You can choose the origin of your feral might or determine it by rolling on the Origin of the Beast table.

entries.caption: Origin of the Beast
rows: One of your parents is a lycanthrope, and you've inherited some of their curse.
You are descended from an archdruid and inherited the ability to partially change shape.
A fey spirit gifted you with the ability to adopt different bestial aspects.
An ancient animal spirit dwells within you, allowing you to walk this path.

subclassFeature.name: Form of the Beast
entries: {@i 3rd-level Path of the Beast feature}

When you enter your rage, you can transform, revealing the bestial power within you. Until the rage ends, you manifest a natural weapon. It counts as a simple melee weapon for you, and you add your Strength modifier to the attack and damage rolls when you attack with it, as normal. Additionally, if you take the attack action on your turn, you can use your bonus action to make one weapon attack with your chosen natural weapon.
You choose the weapon's form each time you rage:

items.name: Bite
items.entry: Your mouth transforms into a bestial muzzle or great mandibles (your choice). It deals {@damage 1d8} piercing damage on a hit. Once on each of your turns when you damage a creature with this bite, you regain a number of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus, provided you have less than half your hit points when you hit.

items.name: Claws
items.entry: Each of your hands transforms into a claw, which you can use as a weapon if it's empty. It deals {@damage 2d4} slashing damage on a hit, which increases to {@damage 2d6} when you reach 10th level in this class.

items.name: Tail
items.entry: You grow a lashing, spiny tail, which deals {@damage 1d8} piercing damage on a hit and has the reach property. If a creature you can see within 10 feet of you hits you with an attack roll, you can use your reaction to swipe your tail and roll a {@dice d8}, applying a bonus to your AC equal to the number rolled, potentially causing the attack to miss you.

subclassFeature.name: Bestial Soul
entries: {@i 6th-level Path of the Beast feature}

The feral power within you increases, causing the natural weapons of your Form of the Beast to count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. In addition, you can now make an additional attack with your natural weapon as part of the attack action, rather than a bonus action.

You can also alter your form to help you adapt to your surroundings. When you finish a short or long rest, choose one of the following benefits, which lasts until you finish your next short or long rest:

items: You gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed, and you can breathe underwater.
You gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed, and you can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.
When you jump, you can make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check and extend your jump by a number of feet equal to the check's total. You can make this special check only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Call the Hunt
entries: {@i 14th-level Path of the Beast feature}

The beast within you grows so powerful that you can spread its ferocity to others and gain resilience from them joining your hunt. When you enter your rage, you can choose a number of other willing creatures you can see equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of one creature).

You gain 5 temporary hit points for each creature that accepts this feature. Until the rage ends, the chosen creatures can each use the following benefit once on each of their turns: when the creature hits a target with an attack roll and deals damage to it, the creature can roll a {@dice d10} and gain a bonus to the damage equal to the number rolled.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Path of Wild Magic
entries: Many places in the multiverse abound with beauty, intense emotion, and rampant magic; the Feywild, the Upper Planes, and other realms of supernatural power radiate with such forces and can profoundly influence people. As folk of deep feeling, barbarians are especially susceptible to these wild influences, with some barbarians being transformed by the magic. These magic-suffused barbarians walk the Path of Wild Magic. Elf, tiefling, aasimar, and genasi barbarians often seek this path, eager to manifest the otherworldly magic of their ancestors.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Surge
entries: {@i 3rd-level Path of Wild Magic feature}
The magical energy roiling inside you sometimes erupts from you. When you enter your rage, roll on the Wild Magic table to determine the magical effect produced.
If the effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

entries.caption: Wild Magic
rows: Shadowy tendrils lash around you. Each creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 1d12} necrotic damage. You also gain {@dice 1d12} temporary hit points.
You teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see. Until your rage ends, you can use this effect again on each of your turns as a bonus action.

An intangible spirit, which looks like a {@creature flumph} or a {@creature pixie} (your choice), appears within 5 feet of one creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you. At the end of the current turn, the spirit explodes, and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} force damage. Until your rage ends, you can use this effect again, summoning another spirit, on each of your turns as a bonus action.

Magic infuses one weapon of your choice that you are holding. Until your rage ends, the weapon's damage type changes to force, and it gains the light and thrown properties, with a normal range of 20 feet and a long range of 60 feet. If the weapon leaves your hand, the weapon reappears in your hand at the end of the current turn.
Whenever a creature hits you with an attack roll before your rage ends, that creature takes {@damage 1d6} force damage, as magic lashes out in retribution.

Until your rage ends, you are surrounded by multi colored, protective lights; Roll a Wrath die. You gain a bonus to your AC equal to half the number rolled (rounded down, minimum of 1), and while within 10 feet of you, your allies gain the same bonus.
Flowers and vines temporarily grow around you. Until your rage ends, the ground within 15 feet of you is {@quickref difficult terrain||3} for your enemies.

A bolt of light shoots from your chest. Another creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} radiant damage and be {@condition blinded} until the start of your next turn. Until your rage ends, you can use this effect again on each of your turns as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Bolstering Magic
entries: {@i 6th-level Path of Wild Magic feature}

You can harness your wild magic to bolster yourself or a companion. As an action, you can touch one creature (which can be yourself) and confer one of the following benefits of your choice to that creature:

items: For 10 minutes, the creature can roll a {@dice d4} whenever making an attack roll or an ability check and add the number rolled to the {@dice d20} roll.

Roll a {@dice d3}. The creature regains one expended spell slot, the level of which equals the number rolled or lower (the creature's choice). Once a creature receives this benefit, that creature can't receive it again until after a long rest.

entries: You can take this action a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Overloaded Surge
entries: {@i 10th-level Path of Wild Magic feature}
The magical energy roiling inside you is stronger than ever. The features you gain from your Wild Magic table are improved in the following ways.

entries.caption: Wild Magic
rows: You can use this effect again as a bonus action on subsequent turns.
You teleport a willing creature that you can touch up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see rather than yourself.
The damage is increased to {@dice 2d6}, and the area is increased to 10 feet. It now also deals half damage if they succeed on the saving throw.
The weapon can now benefit from Reckless attack even when thrown, and no longer gains disadvantage from the long range.
You can now expend a Wrath charge as a bonus action to treat the AC bonus as if you rolled the maximum number on your Wrath die until the start of your next turn.
Any creature that moves 10 feet while within this area must make a Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone}.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Totem Warrior
entries: The Path of the Totem Warrior is a spiritual journey, as the barbarian accepts a spirit animal as guide, protector, and inspiration. In battle, your totem spirit fills you with supernatural might, adding magical fuel to your barbarian rage.
Most barbarian tribes consider a totem animal to be kin to a particular clan. In such cases, it is unusual for an individual to have more than one totem animal spirit, though exceptions exist.

subclassFeature.name: Totem Spirit
entries: {@i 3rd-level Totem Warrior feature}

When you adopt this path, you choose a totem spirit and gain its feature. You must make or acquire a physical totem object—an amulet or similar adornment—that incorporates fur or feathers, claws, teeth, or bones of the totem animal. At your option, you also gain minor physical attributes that are reminiscent of your totem spirit. For example, if you have a bear totem spirit, you might be unusually hairy and thick-skinned, or if your totem is the eagle, your eyes turn bright yellow.
Your totem animal might be an animal related to those listed here but more appropriate to your homeland. For example, you could choose a hawk or vulture in place of an eagle.

subclassFeature.name: Bear
entries: When you enter a rage, you can choose two damage types except psychic to gain resistance to for the duration of the rage.

subclassFeature.name: Eagle
entries: While you're raging and aren't wearing heavy armor, you can take both the {@action Dash} and {@action Disengage} action as a bonus action on your turn. The spirit of the eagle makes you into a predator who can weave through the fray with ease.

subclassFeature.name: Elk
entries: While you're raging and aren't wearing heavy armor, your walking speed increases by 15 feet, and you can ignore the movement penalty of non-magical difficult terrain. The spirit of the elk makes you extraordinarily swift.

subclassFeature.name: Tiger
entries: While raging, you can add 10 feet to your long jump distance and 3 feet to your high jump distance. Whenever you land within 10 feet of a hostile creature after jumping, you gain a Wrath charge. The spirit of the tiger empowers your leaps.

subclassFeature.name: Wolf
entries: While you're raging, your friends have advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature within 10 feet of you that is hostile to you. The spirit of the wolf makes you a leader of hunters.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Beast
entries: {@i 6th-level Totem Warrior feature}
You gain a magical benefit based on a totem animal of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Elephant
entries: You gain the might of an elephant. Your carrying capacity (including maximum load and maximum lift) is doubled, and you have advantage on Strength checks made to push, pull, lift, or break objects.

subclassFeature.name: Owl
entries: You gain the eyesight of an Owl. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Insight} or {@skill Perception} skill. If you already have proficiency in the chosen skill, you gain Expertise in it. Additionally, if your darkvision has a range under 120 feet, its range is now 120 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Ibex
entries: You gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed, and you have advantage on ability checks and saving throws against the {@condition grappled} or {@condition prone} conditions.

subclassFeature.name: Lion
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} or {@skill Acrobatics} skill. If you already have proficiency in the chosen skill, you gain expertise in it instead.

subclassFeature.name: Fox
entries: You gain the hunting sensibilities of a Fox. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} or {@skill Survival} skill. If you already have proficiency in the chosen skill, you gain expertise in it instead.

subclassFeature.name: Totemic Attunement
entries: {@i 14th-level Totem Warrior feature}
You gain a magical benefit based on a totem animal of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Moose
entries: While you're raging, any creature within 10 feet of you that's hostile to you has disadvantage on attack rolls against targets other than you.

subclassFeature.name: Vulture
entries: While raging, you have a flying speed equal to your current walking speed provided you aren't wearing any armor.

subclassFeature.name: Bull
entries: While raging, you can use a bonus action during your move to pass through the space of a creature which is no more than 1 size larger than you. That creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC 8 + your Strength bonus + your proficiency bonus) or be knocked {@condition prone} and take bludgeoning damage equal to Your Constitution modifier times your Wrath die, or take half damage on a succesful save.

subclassFeature.name: Jaguar
entries: While you're raging, if you move or jump at least 20 feet in a straight line toward a creature no more than 1 size larger than you right before making a melee weapon attack against it, you can use a bonus action to make an additional melee weapon attack against it.

subclassFeature.name: Hyena
entries: While you're raging, you land a critical hit on a 19 or a 20 against a creature which is below its maximum hitpoints.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Four Horsemen
entries: The Path of the Four Horsemen is of embracing and inflicting the apocalypse on those whose actions may invoke it. The barbarian, through a god, tribe, event, or an ideal, builds towards inflicting the horrors of the apocalypse onto those whose irredeemable actions demand it.
The barbarian may gradually get rid of aspects of his self that interfere with their chosen ideal, in hopes of turning into the incarnation of their corresponding horseman.

subclassFeature.name: Steed of Testament
entries: {@i 3rd-level Four Horsemen feature}
As an action, you can magically summon the steed that is bound to you. It appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet of you.

The steed is friendly to you and your companions, and it obeys your commands, but can be used as a steed by you and only you. See its game statistics in the accompanying {@creature Spectral Steed|DRK} stat block, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places. You can determine the cosmetic characteristics of the trait, although it must represent the color of your chosen horseman on its mane.

In combat, the steed shares your initiative count, and it takes its turn during yours. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes on its turn is the {@action Dodge} action, unless you take a bonus action on your turn to command it to take another action. That action can be one in its stat block or some other action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, the steed can take any action of its choice, not just {@action Dodge}.

The steed remains until it is reduced to 0 hit points, until you use this feature to summon the steed again, or until you die. Anything the steed was wearing or carrying is left behind when the steed vanishes.
Once you summon the steed, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a use of rage to summon it.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Rider
entries: {@i 3rd-level Four Horsemen feature}

You learn to inflict aspects of the apocalypse on your foes. Choose one of the following aspects of the apocalypse, as a part of it manifests onto yourself. It can be in the form of a tattoo, a trinket, an article of clothing, body paint, or even a scar. The manifestation usually carries the color of the aspect, pale green (death), black (famine), red (death) or white (conquest).

You gain proficiency in the {@skill history} skill, and can double your proficiency bonus on history checks to recall details about historical disasters, wars and pandemics. If you already have proficiency in the history skill, you instead gain proficiency in a skill that you are not proficient in of your choice from the barbarian skill list.

subclassFeature.name: Horseman of Death
entries: When you take damage while raging, you can expend any number of wrath charges as a reaction. Roll a number of wrath die equal to the charges you expended, and reduce the damage taken by the total. The damage is reduced after any relevent resistances, immunities or vulnerabilities.
Your steed can also benefit from this feature if it was hurt by the same instance of damage.

subclassFeature.name: Horseman of War
entries: You can give yourself a bonus to your Initiative rolls equal to your proficiency bonus. Additionally, if you roll a 1 when you roll a wrath die for dealing damage, you do not expend the wrath charge.

subclassFeature.name: Horseman of Famine
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend a Wrath charge to inflict Pestilence. The next time the creature makes an attack roll or a saving throw, it must roll a Wrath Die and reduce that amount from the attack or save.

subclassFeature.name: Horseman of Conquest
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend a Wrath charge to release a burst of energy, pushing the creature. The creature must make a Strength saving throw (DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be pushed 10 feet away from you.
If you are riding your steed, the creature also falls {@condition prone} if it fails the saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Last Judgement
entries: {@i 6th-level Four Horsemen feature}
you have embraced the apocalypse, letting it run rampant through you, inflicting it upon your foes. You gain the following benefits while raging:

items: If you have a higher AC than your steed, it can use your AC instead.
Your steed ignores non-magical difficult terrain.
You can add your constitution modifier to your death saving throws.
If you are affected by {@condition exhaustion}, you can treat it as being 1 level lower than it is.

subclassFeature.name: Relics of Cataclysm
entries: {@i 14th-level Four Horsemen feature}
A part of your horseman fuses within yourself, allowing you to wield their power. You gain a benefit based on the rider you chose at level 3.

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Death
entries: When you drop to 0 hitpoints, you can choose to give yourself a stack of {@condition exhaustion} to drop to 1 hitpoint instead.

subclassFeature.name: Scale of Famine
entries: If a creature with more hitpoints than you deals damage to you, you can use your reaction to make a constitution saving throw as if you were concentrating on a spell. If you succeed on this saving throw, you take no damage.

subclassFeature.name: Blade of War
entries: You no longer provide advantage on attacks against you if you use your reckless attack feature. Additionally, your crit range also improves by 1.

subclassFeature.name: Bow of Conquest
entries: As a part of the bonus action you use to enter Rage, you can infuse a weapon that you are holding for the duration of that rage. The infused weapon gains the Thrown property, with a normal range of 15 feet and a long range of 60 feet. Additionally, thrown attacks made within the normal range of the weapon count as melee attacks. If you throw the weapon, you can make it reappear in your hand after the attack. Additionally, once per turn when you hit a creature with an attack, you deal an additional amount of force damage equal to your barbarian level.

subclassFeature.name: Chronicle of Convulsion
entries: {@i 10th-level Four Horsemen feature}

You learn the {@spell legend lore} spell, and can cast it once per day without expending a spell slot. While you are casting this spell, the visage of your chosen rider covers your face, as you recite the knowledge from the spell.
You and any creature of your choice within 30 feet of you have advantage on Constitution saving throws against {@condition exhaustion} due to malnourishment, extreme weather, or disease.
Your steed now ignores difficult terrain, and can get back up from being {@condition prone} by using only 5 feet of movement.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the World Tree
entries: Barbarians who follow the Path of the World Tree believe that their Rage links them to the cosmic ash tree Yggdrasil. This "World Tree" grows among the Outer Planes, connecting them to each other and to the many worlds of the Material plane, and the greatest plants on the world are said to be distant descendants of mighty Yggdrasil. These barbarians draw on their connection to the world tree as a source of vitality and as a means of travel accross the multiverse.

subclassFeature.name: Vitality of the Tree
entries: {@i 3rd-level World Tree feature}

When you activate your Rage, you regain a number of Hit Points equal to your Barbarian level. At the start of each of your turns while your Rage is active, you can choose another creature within 10 feet of yourself to gain Temporary Hit Points.

To determine the number of Temporary Hit Points, roll {@dice 2d6}. You gain an additional d6 to this roll whenever your Wrath die scales. If any of these Temporary Hit Points remain when your Rage ends, they vanish.

subclassFeature.name: Branches of the Tree
entries: {@i 6th-level World Tree feature}

While your Rage is active, whenever a creature you can see ends its turn within 20 feet of you, you can use your Reaction to summon spectral branches of the World Tree around it. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + your Strength modifier) or be teleported to an unoccupied space you can see within 5 feet of yourself or in the nearest unoccupied space you can see. The space the target teleports to must be on a surface or liquid that can support it; otherwise, the target doesn't teleport.

subclassFeature.name: Battering Roots
entries: {@i 10th-level World Tree feature}

Tendrils of the World Tree extend from your melee weapons. While you wield any melee weapon, your reach with that weapon increases by 10 feet, and when you hit with it, you can activate the Push or Topple property even if you're using another mastery property with that weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Travel along the Tree
entries: {@i 14th-level World Tree feature}

As an action, you touch a Huge or larger tree or a Teleportation Circle to create a link through the World Tree to a Teleportation Circle somewhere else on the same world or on another plance of existence. When you do so, you can specify a target destination in general terms, such as the city of brass on the Elemental Plane of fire, and you and up to five willing creatures within 30 feet of you appear at the teleportation circle closest to that destination. If a Teleportation Circle is too small to hold all the creatures you transported, they appear in the unoccupied spaces closest to the circle.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Long Rest. If you've run out of uses of this feature, you can expend three uses of your Rage, choosing to activate this feature instead of Rage.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Supreme Mind
entries: You realise that you have a guest residing inside you. Whether your will is your own or the creature's is unclear because it seems that they have merged together completely. As you ascertain yourself as a being of one mind and two bodies in a symbiosis, your abilities seem to reflect your change. As you gain levels in this class, your control over your mutation increases and you will be able to pioneer a path that has never been explored before.

subclassFeature.name: Awakening
entries: You can now communicate telepathically with one creature within 60 ft of you at a time and they can respond back to you telepathically. The creature must not be hostile to you and must understand atleast one language. You also understand and can communicate in Deep Speech.

As part of the bonus action when you enter rage and as a bonus action while raging you can attempt to grapple a creature. If a creature is moved forcibly while being grappled by you, you also move to keep grappling the creature. The amount of movement used up in such a way cannot exceed your total movement speed and is reduced from the distance you can move on your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Transmogrification
entries: When attempting to grapple, you can do so telekinetically as translucent tentacles visible only to you and the target creature, wraps around the target creature. The maximum range for the telekinetic grapple extends to within 10 ft of you or upto the reach of your melee weapon, if it is higher. You also get to choose the focus of your path from the two options listed below. You can choose a different option each time you get to choose a new focus.

Mind Path - You are immune to magic that allows other creatures to read your thoughts or determine whether you are lying. Creatures can communicate telepathically with you only if you allow it. You gain resistance to psychic dmg.

Body Path - When a creature is grappled and as a bonus action while it is grappled, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or take psychic dmg equal to one roll of your wrath die + strength modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Metamorphosis
entries: You have immunity to the {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} conditions while your Rage is active and you have advantage against such effects while not raging. When a grappled creature deals damage to you or breaks free from your grapple, you can immediately use your reaction and a wrath charge to attack the target creature and on a hit, you add the number rolled on the wrath die to the damage dealt. You also get to choose the focus of your path from the two options listed below. You can now change any of your selected focuses to another one during a long rest.
Mind Path - Whenever you take more than 10 damage while raging, you can deal psychic dmg to the grappled creature equal to two rolls of your wrath die.

Body Path - When you are grappling a creature and you use the reckless attack feature, the grappled creature must roll a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) and on a failure, it is stunned until the start of your next turn. This effect is dispelled from the grappled creature if your rage ends or if it is not grappled by you anymore.

subclassFeature.name: Transcendent Causatum
entries: When attempting to grapple a creature telekinetically, a translucent illithid form of you appears instead of tentacles, and is visible only to you and the target creature. Your illithid form is one size larger than you and grows or shrinks to maintain the size difference if your size changes. When you successfully grapple a creature or start your turn while grappling a creature, you gain one charge of wrath. You also get to choose the focus of your path from the two options listed below. You can now change any of your selected focuses to another one during a short rest.

Mind Path - A grappled creature benefitting from magical effects or any feature that help it end the grappled condition on itself, must succeed on a Wisdom ability check against your Strength ability check to be able to use those features. You have advantage on this Strength ability check if you are raging. You can spend one minute concentrating on a restrained or incapacitated creature and it is charmed by you at the end of that duration. The charmed condition lasts for 24 hrs and you can telepathically communicate with it during this time, if it is on the same plane of existence as you.
